rank_247.title: A seismic change
rank_247.text:
With only a couple of days to go to the election, it is clear that the United Kingdom Independence party will make gains that go far beyond anything we expected a couple of months ago. It also seems likely that in many regions, a majority of voters will cast their votes for Eurosceptic parties. This is an historic development, a seismic change. To quote Prescott's phrase, the tectonic plates are moving.

Across the EU, Eurosceptic parties are on the march.

All the established parties will have to reappraise their policies on the EU. Blair will have to abandon his hopes of joining the euro, or of ratifying the constitution. Even the Liberal Democrats may need to rethink their Euro-quisling stance.

For the Tories, this is a wake-up call. The party leadership has been trying to bridge the gap between the old dinosaurs - Clarke and Heseltine - and the vast bulk of the members and activists. But in the effort to keep a few distinguished Europhiles on-side, we are letting party activists and the public slip away.

Overwhelmingly, Conservatives want a relationship with the EU based on market access, free trade, voluntary intergovernmental cooperation - and nothing more. Over and over, they say: "In [the referendum of] 1975, we voted for a common market, not political union."

We have to respond to this demand, or become irrelevant to the debate. It is not enough merely to reject the euro and the constitution and to repatriate the common fisheries policy. We need to disengage from the acquis communautaire across a broad front. We need to repeal the 1972 European Communities Act and the European convention on human rights. We need to commit ourselves clearly to the independence and self-determination of our country.

Tony Blair will call this "withdrawal" - although I myself prefer Bill Cash's phrase "associate membership". But it doesn't matter what we call it. What matters is the substance, not the semantics. This is what the British people want. This is what the Conservative party must deliver.

And of course only a party capable of forming a government in Westminster can deliver. Ukip, a mere fringe pressure group, can talk a good story, but can achieve nothing. That is why Eurosceptics, whatever their doubts, should vote Conservative, not Ukip, on Thursday.

rank_273.title: Howard fights for Eurosceptic vote
rank_273.text:
Michael Howard tried to hitch a ride on the growing tide of Euroscepticism today, following Tony Blair's insistence that neither the Tories nor the Liberal Democrats have found the "big argument" to defeat Labour yet.

In a campaign speech in High Wycombe, the Tory leader accused the prime minister of making "huge concessions ... that will be bad for Britain" on the negotiations over the proposed EU constitution.

Mr Howard, who is facing a mounting challenging for the Eurosceptic vote from the UK Independence party, said: "amendments opposing a European foreign minister, a European public prosecutor and a new system of majority voting have all been rejected.

"The truth is that Tony Blair's red lines are just a red herring to divert attention from the huge concessions he has made - even though he knows they will be bad for Britain".

Mr Blair, meanwhile, dismissed the Tory party's challenge to Labour, as a new poll signalled large-scale voter rejection of both Labour and the Tories in this Thursday's elections.

Yet the prime minister rejected suggestions that he was facing a sea change in British politics.

"I think these things change when a big argument comes back the other way that wins," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

"That is what happened with us before 1997. New Labour was a winning political argument.

"For the first time you had the Labour party, a progressive political party, saying you can combine economic efficiency with social justice.

"I don't notice that coming back from either of the two main parties now.

"When that happens, when you actually see that big argument come the other way, then I think you are at a moment of change, but I don't notice that at the moment."

Renewed predictions that Labour will do badly in Thursday's European and local council elections were confirmed by today's poll, which indicates that the two main parties may get the backing of just one in six adults in the European and local government elections.

The Populus poll, published in the Times today - on deadline day for postal ballots to be sent - suggested that Tory support in the European elections could fall from 36% in 1999 to about 24% this time round, while Labour support could slip from 28% to 25-26%.

The Tories' woes, due in part to them haemorrhaging support to the UK Independence party, would overshadow what also looks set to be a bad night for Labour.

Ukip could see its support rise from 7% to about 13% - largely at the expense of the Tories.

The Lib Dems look set to increase their number of Euro MPs and see off the challenge from the Ukip to take third place. But the anti-EU party could also gain more seats in the European parliament.

The poll also showed a majority of Tory supporters (57%) want Britain to pull out of the EU - Ukip's defining aim. The wider public favours staying in by 52.5% to 47.5%.

The government would also lose local government seats to both the Tories and the Lib Dems if the poll were to prove accurate.

The poll had further bad news for the government, showing one in seven voters in the all-postal ballot trial areas had not received ballot papers by last weekend.

The parties are campaigning fiercely to try and woo voters as the deadline for ballots looms.

The 14 million eligible voters in the four northern regions have until tonight to mark their preferences in the local and European elections, with just two days to go before Super Thursday.

Thousands of voters in the rest of the country who opted for all-postal ballot are under the same deadline.

Labour is sending a fleet of cabinet ministers to campaign across the country, including David Blunkett in the South West region, Charles Clarke in the Northern region, Peter Hain in Wales and Tessa Jowell in London.

Labour was focusing on the NHS as it sought to persuade voters to judge it on public services and not the war in Iraq.

The Tory leader, Michael Howard, is taking his charm offensive to the south-east while the Liberal Democrats were today unveiling their latest bid for votes with a new poster campaign.

rank_202.title: Ukip soars in voter backlash
rank_202.text:
Electorate turns against Brussels across continent Table: see the results as they come in

The UK Independence party last night spearheaded a determined assault on the British political establishment in the European elections when they helped force the Labour and Conservative share of the vote down to barely half of the total, and narrowly pushed the Liberal Democrats into fourth place.

Across the country results gave consistent encouragement to Ukip, whose election star was Robert Kilroy-Silk, the former Labour MP and TV personality. He won the first of two Ukip seats in the East Midlands.

As Ukip headed for a dozen seats - compared with the three it won in 1999 - Labour appeared to be right in predicting the Tories had suffered most of the defections. The British National party also appeared to have lost out to Ukip in the rightwing contest.

A rising tide of Euroscepticism with profoundly significant implications was evident in voting across Europe yesterday. But Ukip fell short of the spectacular breakthrough in British politics which it - and several polls - had predicted in its attempt to become a mass movement which aims to enfranchise voters ignored by the big parties.

However, its surge has caught a mood of voter disaffection which also boosted the anti-war Liberal Democrats and the leftwing Respect party. But George Galloway, the ex-Labour MP, did not win a seat and cabinet ministers, loyally backing the beleaguered Tony Blair, insisted they remain on course to win a third term - despite Europe, the Iraq factor and voter scepticism about public service reform.

The likely final result may give the Tories 27 of the 78 seats, Labour 19, Lib Dems and Ukip a dozen, the Greens two.

For Downing Street there was some comfort in the news from across Europe that governing parties were being punished by alienated voters, who were also backing Eurosceptic parties in unprecedented numbers. At 38% the UK turnout, 14% up, was a record high, bucking the wider EU trend.

Labour came second last night, compared with third in Thursday's council elections. With 10 out of 11 regions declared Ukip had edged into third place.

Ukip gained its first seat in London, and a second seat in the South West as it clearly hurt the Tories harder than Labour, which held its two Scottish and two Welsh seats against some odds. The Liberal Democrats won a seat in the north-east. Martin Bell, the ex-BBC Independent, retired after failing in the eastern region.

Early today the BBC computer suggested that the Tories will emerge on around 28% (down 8%), Labour will be on 21% (7% below its poor 1999 result), and Ukip on 18%, ahead of the Lib Dems on 15%. The Greens' Caroline Lucas hung on to her seat in the South East.

The spectacle of Mr Kilroy-Silk being outdone in Eurosceptic rhetoric by the Tories' Roger Helmer at the count in Northampton illustrated the big problem ahead for Tony Blair and Michael Howard. "The forces of national liberation are on the march and will not take No for an answer," Mr Helmer said. Mr Kilroy-Silk denounced the "corrupt, dictatorial regime in Brussels".

The prime minister's aides dismissed claims by Mr Kilroy-Silk and his allies that Mr Blair will now not dare to sign a final version of the EU constitution at this week's Brussels summit.

"If he does he'll lose the referendum very heavily," said Ukip MEP Nigel Farage, who complained that the media had consistently neglected Ukip over Europe. "The entire political class is heading in one direction and ordinary Britons are heading in the opposite direction," he said.

Senior Labour strategists believe that Ukip will have the opposite effect by frightening voters with its talk of quitting the EU and polarising debate. "If Ukip does well it will make the referendum more, not less winnable," predicted a key Blair ally.

The problem is as acute for the Tories. If Mr Howard tilts towards a harder anti-EU line, he may split his party, as the veteran pro-European Kenneth Clarke made clear yesterday. If he fails to respond to the Ukip challenge, more Tory supporters may defect unless they accept Lord Tebbit's warning yesterday: another shot across the Tory bow at the general election may hole Mr Howard's boat, he said on BBC1's Breakfast with Frost.

Labour officials were relieved. "The Tories have got a civil war on their hands," said one survivor of the SDP split that rendered Labour divided and impotent through much of the 1980s. In 1983 Michael Foot narrowly avoided third place against the SDP/Liberal Alliance.

But last night's fresh evidence of the break-up of the historic duopoly of the past 75 years offers no comfort to either main party. No election since the unique postwar "coupon election" of 1918 has seen the share of the vote enjoyed by both top parties fall below 25%.

Labour's chairman, Ian McCartney, said: "Before the campaign, the Tories said in a presentation to their own MEPs they wanted to get 42% in these elections, 'enough to win a general election'. Far from getting 42%, the Tories have failed dramatically to get anywhere near to the 36% that William Hague got in 1999, two years before they suffered a landslide defeat."

Conservative co-chairman Dr Liam Fox said: "The Conservatives won these elections, just as we won the local elections and the Greater London assembly elections. We got the highest share of the vote and have the most MEPs. Labour's result is the worst result of a governing party in British electoral history."

Britain's higher turnout was in marked contrast to the rest of Europe, where in the biggest election in the continent's history the 25-state average was 44.6%, a record low, and just 28.7% among the 10 new members.

rank_287.title: Charles Grant: It's time to do your homework
rank_287.text:
For the past seven years Britain has been led by the most pro-European prime minister since Ted Heath, yet the mood of the country has never been more Europhobic. A constant stream of anti-European propaganda has helped to turn public opinion against the EU, the euro and the constitutional treaty that is under discussion in Brussels today. Too few politicians have been willing to fight back and expose the lies peddled by the sceptics. Tony Blair gives the occasional pro-European speech, but few of his ministers follow suit. So it is hardly surprising that the sceptics have, for now, won the argument about Europe.

The problem with the Labour leadership is not Euroscepticism, but rather indifference. Not many cabinet ministers know much about the EU, are interested, or think it matters. Of course, there are pro-Europeans, such as Charles Clarke, Patricia Hewitt and Geoff Hoon. But when was the last time that one of them found the courage to make a big speech on the virtues of the EU or its draft constitution? Too often, politicians seem to think that if they speak out on Europe they will invoke the wrath of the tabloids and harm their careers. The same caution presumably explains why Labour decided to campaign in the last two European elections by talking as little as possible about Europe - a tactic that evidently failed.

The cumulative effect of this lack of leadership is that the centre of gravity of the European debate has shifted, in only a few years, from "Should we join the euro?" to "Should we quit the EU?" That shift, combined with the decision to hold a referendum on the EU constitutional treaty, poses great dangers for Britain.

Legally, the treaty cannot enter into force unless all 25 members ratify it by parliamentary vote or referendum. At least half a dozen are likely to hold referendums. Many Britons - including, it seems, cabinet ministers - assume that another country is bound to vote No, so it doesn't matter very much which way Britain votes.

The truth, however, is that a No vote would have profound consequences for Britain and for Europe. There is a fair chance that all the other countries will adopt the constitution; in none of them is Euroscepticism so rampant as in Britain. If Britain alone cannot ratify, the others could try to expel it. In practice there would not be the required unanimity: Britain has many friends, notably among the Nordics and central Europeans, who would be loath to have an EU without Britain.

But no one should assume that if the British vote No, all the others will happily abandon their efforts to improve the way EU institutions work. France and Germany would probably lead a group of like-minded members into the creation of an avant-garde committed to closer integration. Jacques Chirac would not be the only leader who would want to seize the opportunity of a British No to set up a "core Europe" that excluded Britain and some of the troublesome central Europeans. This would have its own institutions and might focus on subjects such as economic policy coordination in the euro zone, corporate taxation, foreign policy, migration and criminal law. The existing EU would remain as an outer circle for Britain and other faint-hearted countries.

Of course, Britain may not be the only country to reject the constitutional treaty. But if several countries turned it down, a core Europe would still be the most likely outcome (this assumes that France adopts the treaty, as it probably will; if France did not, both the constitutional treaty and the idea of an avant-garde would be dead). The British should not under-estimate the political will in several European capitals in favour of a new institutional club. Outside the core, Britain would still have access to the single market. But it would pay a heavy political and economic price.

Excluded from many of the decisions that shaped the continent's future, Britain would often have to choose between following or opposing the leading group. Staying out of the euro is already causing problems. Last month's report from the Economist Intelligence Unit shows that the UK's share of foreign direct investment into the EU-15 fell from 28% in 1999 - the year the euro was created - to 5% in 2003. Membership of an outer circle would make Britain seem an even more peripheral country.

Tony Blair needs to order his ministers to do some homework on the treaty and learn how to dispel the many myths surrounding it. They must go out and explain the good things in the document, and the countless benefits of EU membership. The referendum can be won, but only if politicians find the courage to make the case for Europe, and keep doing it. Otherwise Britain will leave the European mainstream.

· Charles Grant is director of the Centre for European Reform

rank_295.title: Press review: What they said about the European parliament
rank_295.text:
"With little suspense, and even less openness, Josep Borrell was elected yesterday to the presidency of the world's largest freely elected legislature," said theafter the 57-year-old Catalan socialist became president of the European parliament.

Mr Borrell won the post thanks to a pact between the centre-right European People's party (EPP) and the Party of European Socialists (PSE) to share control of the EU legislature over its five-year term. The WSJE felt the deal would do nothing to combat Euroscepticism. "European democracy won't be built in a day," it said. "But the parliament would be the place to start, if ever a start is made."

Germany's Die Welt agreed the parliament should not be involved "in this kind of wheeling and dealing". It, too, complained of the "great harm done to democracy", which is something "the EU urgently needs".

However, the Süddeutsche Zeitung thought the election had gone off "without a hitch", and joked about "a fascinating group of MEPs from 25 countries having its usual political drama". While some German conservatives might be upset by the election of a socialist, it said, "German domestic politics should never set the tone in the European parliament".

Yves Mény in France's Ouest-France was in complete agreement. "The lesson to draw is simple: no party, no country, is in a position to impose its will on the European parliament. It will be crucial to construct coalitions."

In Spain, El País defended Mr Borrell's triumph, which was the result of "complex balances that have always characterised the European parliament". However, it conceded that despite his experience of domestic politics - he is a former minister - he "did not have a great deal of experience in Europe".

That should not matter, said Reiner Wandler in the German paper Die Tageszeitung. Mr Borrell's "stated goal, to bring people closer to Europe and make it more understandable to them", is a "very worthwhile ambition", especially given the low turnouts in last month's European elections. And just when Mr Borrell's political career seemed to have come to an end, "he has succeeded in making a comeback".

rank_307.title: Ian Black: Drama at the EU
rank_307.text:
José Manuel Barroso had thought he would be presenting a dream team to the European parliament today. Instead he is embroiled in a nightmare row over politics and morality in a power struggle that has injected rare passion and drama into an EU debate - and might, just, end up bringing ordinary people a little closer to the distant institutions that represent them.

It was not clear last night whether, or how, the fight over Rocco Buttiglione, Italy's controversial candidate for the Brussels executive - the commissioner-designate for justice and home affairs - can be resolved after a marathon bout of horsetrading in the Strasbourg assembly. If it is not, then many MEPs will be cock-a-hoop. But it will be at the cost of plunging the EU into a grave and unprecedented crisis.

In any event, this is the worst start for Barroso, Maoist revolutionary turned centre-right Portuguese prime minister, taking over the presidency from the lacklustre Romano Prodi just as the EU adjusts to the reality of having 25 members and 450 million people - and is about to start years of difficult accession talks with Turkey.

On Friday, heads of government gather in Rome for a ceremony to sign the new constitutional treaty. This is designed to make the union function more efficiently and democratically. But with referendums looming in several countries, including Britain, and apathy and Euroscepticism as bad as ever, it may never take effect. And then next week the EU will have to come to terms with the result of the US presidential election, with many leaders rooting privately for John Kerry, and thus risking exaggerated expectations of a man who may speak French and like working with allies, but will probably be unable to deliver a significantly better relationship between the old and new continents. Europe, so often trapped in the gap between aspiration and reality, does not seem poised to play a bigger, more coherent role in the world stage.

That global role, though, must begin at home, and Buttiglione is not the only joker in the commission pack: MEPs also raised objections to the Dutch businesswoman appointed to take over the competition portfolio, the Hungarian unsuited to managing energy and the Danish agriculture commissioner married to a farmer enriched by CAP subsidies.

None of these candidates generated much interest beyond the Brussels beltway. But the Italian conservative and friend of the Pope has raised hackles because of his views on homosexuality, single mothers and the family - classic beliefs of the conservative Catholic that he is. Feelings ran just as high during negotiations on the EU constitution, with the Italian, Polish and Irish governments - backed by the Vatican - demanding a clear reference to Christian values, but being defeated by the secular-minded majority which decided, correctly, that this would be the wrong message to send to Europe's multicultural societies - with 12 million Muslims, as well as those Turkish wannabes.

Buttiglione was justified in arguing that there is a difference between law and morality, and he is entitled to his private views. But he showed a breathtaking lack of judgment in answering MEPs' questions the way he did. The row escalated when his supporters protested about an anti-Catholic "inquisition". Yet there is no such inquisition. Joe Borg, the Maltese commission candidate, is a staunch opponent of abortion, but that is irrelevant to his duties running fisheries policy. It is understandable that Barroso did not wish to cede too much ground to parliament. But he was foolish to reject a reshuffle that could have ended this fight quickly and simply.

Some of this is the inevitable outcome of the sheer com plexity of the EU's hybrid, Heath Robinson structures. Buttiglione was nominated by Silvio Berlusconi just as Peter Mandelson was by Tony Blair, for similar reasons of domestic politics and the desire to set the policy agenda. The appointed commission president then has to find jobs for these national nominees - who must all pass muster in today's all-or-nothing vote by MEPs.

It is a good idea for the European parliament to have a bigger say in the make-up of the union's supranational executive (those "Brussels bureaucrats" beloved of British newspapers) and disingenuous to say it should not have one because of poor turnout - a dismal 44% last June - in the European elections. Most people know little about an institution routinely scorned as a talking shop on a gravy train - though some may remember the jaw-dropping gaffe last year when Berlusconi compared a German MEP to a Nazi camp guard. Extraordinary misjudgments and a vicious skirmish over institutional power have come together to create a moment where the stakes for Europe's disenchanted union of states and peoples are suddenly very high.

· Ian Black left Brussels this summer after four years as the Guardian's European editor

ian.black@theguardian.com

rank_227.title: Mandelson sets out vision of EU business reform
rank_227.text:
Peter Mandelson told the CBI conference today Euroscepticism was "an unwanted by-product" of Labour's economic successes and could only be defeated by an "unwavering pursuit of economic reform".

In his first major speech as incoming EU trade commissioner Mr Mandelson, who characterised himself as a pro-European reformer, said: "Let's not make the mistake of the anti-Europeans and confuse criticism of some European polices with rejection of Europe."

He warned: "At present the prospect is of Europe's relative economic decline in the world" and said EU nations must raise their game by becoming "cutting-edge innovators".

In remarks that will please the unions, Mr Mandelson held up Finland, Sweden and Denmark as models Europe should be following because of their combination of "economic dynamism with greater social cohesion".

The goal, he said, was to marry "British-style economic openness and flexibility" with continental-style investment in social and economic infrastructure, scientific research and development and public service.

Mr Mandelson told delegates in Birmingham: "I recognise that in this hall and in the wider British business community there is not as much pro-European fervour as perhaps 10 or 15 years ago.

"In part, this is an unwanted by-product of the Labour government's economic record.

"In former times, successive British governments had so messed up the running of the economy that British business looked longingly to the continent, and particularly Germany, as an anchor and a model of partnership in place of our chaotic industrial relations.

"Today Britain seems to offer its own distinctive model of economic success. I'm proud of the country's economic achievement - but let's have no exaggerated gloating."

The warning is likely to be seen as a coded snub to the chancellor, Gordon Brown, who has been involved in a semi-public row with Alan Milburn.

Mr Milburn supplanted Mr Mandelson as Labour's election strategist, over the extent to which the party should campaign on its economic record in the forthcoming general election.

It was essential to reinforce public confidence in the EU because trading blocs were emerging around the world and the economic power balance was "changing at breathtaking speed", Mr Mandelson said. "Think of the dramatic rise of China and India. Think of the potential of Brazil and South Africa."

He said that more American-style dynamism was needed in Europe, but "without emulating the raw divisions of America's more polarised society".

He warned: "At the hi-tech end of business, with some notable exceptions and particular strengths in sectors like mobile telephony and civil aviation, Europe is being outsmarted and outgunned."

American firms accounted for 46% of the world's top 300 firms ranked in terms of research and development, he said.

Mr Mandelson's speech comes ahead of a statement in the Commons this afternoon by the prime minister on his attendance at a European council meeting on Friday.

In a question-and-answer session after his speech, Mr Mandelson suggested last week's north-east referendum had put paid to the plans of the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, for regional assemblies.

The local government minister, Nick Raynsford, has said polls will still be held in the north-west and inYorkshire and Humberside despite last week's overwhelming rejection in the region where support for the idea was strongest.

However, Mr Mandelson said it was "pointless" to debate whether assemblies best expressed regional identity.

"The people of the north-east have had their say. It is an idea, in their view, whose time has gone, if it ever arrived," he said.

"I happen to see an argument for it, but the public don't embrace it and I don't think it is going to come back in that form."

Mr Mandelson was expected to have been confirmed in his new job by the time he spoke to the CBI, but he is still officially a "commissioner designate" following the technical withdrawal of the new team in the row with the European parliament over plans to appoint Rocco Buttiglione, who provoked controversy with remarks on single mothers and homosexuality.

With Mr Buttiglione and one other - Latvian - member of the original new team now replaced, the appointment of the 25-strong commission, including Mr Mandelson, should be a formality in a vote of European MPs in Strasbourg on November 18.

Mr Mandelson said: "I had hoped that this speech would be my first public engagement as the new European commissioner for trade. I had forgotten what long experience in politics has taught me: never take anything for granted."

rank_292.title: 'It's a very good thing. Now people can see what the options were'
rank_292.text:
'It's a very good thing. Now people can see what the options were'

John Major is angry. He believes the "myths and downright misrepresentation" that surround September 16 1992, the day that came to define his government, have obscured the economic success that followed. He is angry about the way Labour has taken the credit for economic growth; angry at the way Black Wednesday has been demonised by Eurosceptics; angry about what he sees as the manipulation of the Freedom of Information Act. Angry too about claims that his own performance on the day contributed to the calamity.

Yesterday's publication of the Black Wednesday documents will, he hopes, put the myths to rest. "People will see the raw, unadulterated documents. I think it is a very good thing for history," he says. "People for the first time will see what the policy options were, what the difficulties were and what the long-term benefit has been."

On no issue is this defiance stronger than his own behaviour. He rejects as "black propaganda" rumours that he was unable to cope as the markets destroyed the pound. Reports that he had a breakdown are "utter rubbish", he says. "That was a bit of post-event destabilisation."

That is not to say he found Black Wednesday easy. It was a day of "desperate difficulty", he recalls, though there was no panic. When he woke that morning in Admiralty House (Downing Street was being renovated) he did not know what was to come. "It wasn't apparent until the morning began to move on quite how difficult it was going to be."

Admiralty House presented its own difficulties too. Some have described an isolated prime minister cut off from the Downing Street machine. He agrees there were problems - "we didn't have all the familiar immediate information" - but insists "we were not seriously out of date".

"We didn't have a market screen but we had officials coming in and out."

Many have suggested in retrospect that Britain should have suspended its ERM membership earlier. Not so, says Mr Major. "We had an obligation under the ERM to defend the pound."

Norman Lamont, chancellor on the day and the man who finally had to announce to the world that his policy had fallen apart, might question that. But Mr Major insists that at the time there was no dis agreement. "On that day we sat together and we worked together," he says. "It is not the case that there were loads of disputes between us on that day. Norman supported our membership of the ERM."

Pointing to the great pile of documents made public yesterday lunchtime, he insists they do not reveal a government split over how to manage the economy. "Norman has made it absolutely clear that we would not have got inflation down without the ERM and we would not have moved to the excellent economy we have now got if we hadn't got inflation down," he says.

Political crisis

So was it a crisis at all? Yes, says Mr Major, but a political crisis, not an economic one. In the end the public, he hopes, "will place the £3.3bn cost against an economy without inflation that has lasted for 13 years and is certainly worth far more than £3.3bn". The disaster that followed Britain's exit certainly hit the Tory party. It is "beyond a doubt" that Black Wednesday encouraged Conservative Euroscepticism, he says - and that, in the end, killed the government.

Since autumn 1992 his party has struggled in the polls, rarely rising above the mid-30s. That might change, he thinks, if his party was prepared to be bullish about what it achieved. "It should be, shouldn't it?" he says - the closest he gets to criticising his successors as party leader. "I think the Conservative party should take credit for the fact that they handed over an economic legacy unmatched in recent years." That does not take away from the humiliation of the day. "It was always a marginal decision in my mind whether I should have resigned. I didn't. If you ask me today was it the right decision I would still not be absolutely certain."

He has no doubt, though, about what is wrong with the Freedom of Information Act. "It is quite extraordinary really that it opens up the actions of former govern ments to substantial if not complete disclosure and blocks off similar disclosures to the current government. I don't think that is equitable," he says.

Oliver Letwin yesterday said the act was being used by Labour to generate propaganda. "It does look as if it is being operated in that way," Mr Major says. "Whether this is accidental or malign it is difficult to tell," he adds - refusing to blame Alastair Campbell, a man he described yesterday as "below my eyeline". He is clear on one point: he did not try to block the release of the documents as the Times alleged in a recent report that drove him to fury.

What the papers prove above all, he believes, is that his government killed inflation. "In time all this will be placed in a proper context," he says. "Before the release of these documents it was subject to myth, to mythology and to downright misrepresentation."

"Now that can't happen. So I am pleased that it has actually been published."

Events that brought down the pound - and the Tory party

1987

Then chancellor Nigel Lawson begins informally shadowing the mark in an attempt to give Britain German-style low inflation.

October 1990

John Major, then chancellor, takes Britain into the European Exchange Rate Mechanism (ERM) - a grid system designed to tie currencies closely together in narrow fluctuation bands - at DM2.95 to the pound. The rate was widely seen as being too high and too restrictive - the pound could only fluctuate by 6% either side of the central rate.

April 1992

Major, as prime minister, wins a fourth election for the Conservatives.

Mid-1992

Germany raises interest rates to a record 8.75% to deal with its own inflation. Britain was forced to raise rates too, to defend the pound's rate, but at a time the economy was already in a deep recession with unemployment rising towards 3 million.

August 1992

Meeting of European finance ministers and central bank chiefs in Bath. Major and his chancellor, Norman Lamont, try to persuade Bundesbank chief Helmut Schlesinger to cut German interest rates to relieve pressure on the pound. He refuses.

September 14

Italy devalues the lira in exchange for a small rate cut from the Buba. Markets turn their attention to sterling, especially with the Buba hinting that sterling might be devalued.

September 16

Black Wednesday. The day dawns with the pound under intense strain at the bottom of its permitted band (DM2.778). Speculators, led by the Hungarian-born financier George Soros, are circling like vultures. "It was an obvious bet, a one-way bet," he said later.

9am

Major and some of his cabinet are camped in Admiralty Arch in Whitehall while No 10 is undergoing renovations and so are out of touch with news agency reports of what is happening in the markets. "I knew very early on the game was up but could not convince my colleagues," Lamont said later. Over in the City, the Bank of England continues intervening, as it has to under ERM rules, buying billions of pounds on the foreign exchanges in a bid to hold the pound in its band.

11am

Major and Lamont announce interest rates are to rise immediately from 10% to 12% in an attempt to stop the downward pressure on the pound by improving the attraction of holding sterling.

12.45pm

"It hasn't worked - they are still selling," Lamont tells Major. Cabinet holds crisis meeting.

2.15pm

Lamont and Major decide to raise interest rates from 12% to 15%, effective the following day, in a desperate, last-ditch attempt to save the pound, their reputation and their government. It fails, and the selling continues.

7.40pm

Lamont walks out of the Treasury to tell the world that Britain is leaving the ERM. He takes back the second rate rise, leaving rates at 12%. The pound tumbles below its old ERM rate against the market. The government's defeat is total, its reputation in shreds.

"I went to bed half convinced my days as prime minister were drawing to a close ... we had suffered a great defeat," Major said later.

September 17

Lamont announces interest rates are being cut back to 10% again. The government has lost billions defending the pound. Soros is said to have pocketed £1bn of that and becomes known as "the man who broke the Bank of England".

rank_305.title: Dutch prepare to deliver their snub
rank_305.text:
Dutch government leaders yesterday issued desperate pleas for the public to back the European constitution as the Netherlands, in the shadow of the French vote, prepared to deliver a large snub to the EU.

Three days before the Dutch vote in their sole referendum of modern times, opinion polls at the weekend put the no camp comfortably ahead, confirming a trend that has held consistently for more than a month.

The poll findings gave the no camp a lead of 14 points, with a 3% margin of error. For more than a month, several opinion polls each week have highlighted a strong if surprising wave of Euroscepticism in the Netherlands. The weekend surveys indicated that the lacklustre yes campaign was staging a mild recovery, but not enough to shift the balance when the country votes on Wednesday.

The unpopular Christian Democrat prime minister, Jan Peter Balkenende, appearing on Dutch television yesterday before the result of the French referendum was known, sounded forlorn about the probable imminent rejection of a constitution he helped negotiate.

He urged voters not to listen to the message delivered by the French electorate, but to make up their own minds. All the signs, however, are that the Dutch have already taken that advice, with the polls showing firmer opposition to the constitution than in France.

The impact of the French result remains to be seen. Maurice de Hond, a pollster whose latest survey put the no camp ahead 57-43, said an expected low turnout would be even more meagre following the French snub.

rank_132.title: Jackie Ashley: This bout of Eurobashing is shameful and dangerous
rank_132.text:
He's starting to protest too much. "I am not a Eurosceptic," Tony Blair told his solitary press conference in Paris on Tuesday, after a chilly meeting with President Chirac. "Britain has got a government which is not Eurosceptic, but believes in Britain at the centre of Europe," he told the Commons yesterday. So now we know. This British prime minister is no sceptic, but has become a believer in the EU in just the same way that Margaret Thatcher was - Europe is fine, he reckons, if it's his Europe, on his terms. The Europe that causes problems is the one messed up by a load of bloody Europeans.

His language about the British rebate negotiation was less strident than Lady Thatcher would have used, but his coldly crisp assessment of "sharp disagreement" that will be difficult to bridge in Brussels today was as tough as anything he's said before an EU summit. Euroscepticism is as fashionable in London this summer as peasant and Gypsy costumes are in the Paris shops; where once it was dominated by rightwing men in ageing green blazers and regimental ties, now it is cool and moderate. Now it is New Labour.

To get a real sense of the challenge facing the British centre-left, we have to stand back a bit. The euro, which was meant to be fundamental to EU development, is completely off the Labour agenda, while on the continent the first voices calling for it to be unwound are being raised. A British referendum on the constitution is off the agenda too, which is reasonable given what happened in France and the Netherlands; but there is no plan, or even germ of an idea, about how to proceed. And by linking the British rebate to agricultural spending reform, London has effectively put the EU budget issue into cold storage.

So, to recap, the EU is in fine condition, except for its budget, its political system and its currency. Of course, it has faced many a crisis and always seems to muddle through. Yet this time a lot is at stake, and for Britain as much as anywhere. If the EU contracts in some radical way to an "old Europe" core, then we will be outside it, and many of the workplace and legal protections the centre-left so values will be at risk. An outer-ring Europe will have to be lower wage, more ruthless and less social democratic to survive. And if the EU actually began to collapse, as so many blithe spirits hope, the result would be far worse. Trade barriers would go up again, those borders would begin to reappear and prosperity would slide.

Those who are so cheerily hailing the current chaos in Europe as just what Britain wanted should pause for thought. Imagine, for a moment, a world in which the EU did not exist. It would be a world dominated by the ruthless and often protectionist power of the United States, not balanced by any competing western system, and by the rising low-cost juggernauts of Asia. What price then a modern social-welfare state on our small cluster of offshore islands?

So the pressure on Tony Blair to manage his way through this crisis as Britain takes over the rotating presidency of the EU is intense. Yet the mood of casual Euroscepticism on the left is now so strong that there's a real chance of the prime minister shrugging and blocking his way to the end of the year. There's very little pressure at home for him to do anything else.

In cabinet discussions before his trip to Moscow, Berlin and Paris, there was a fierce debate about both the future of the constitution and the necessity to hold on to Britain's rebate. But Europhile ministers such as Patricia Hewitt and Charles Clarke apparently felt themselves pushed against the wall by the mood of hostility.

Jack Straw spoke at great length, and passionately, about the iniquities of the continental elites. Neither he nor the prime minister had advance warning of Peter Mandelson's carefully worded pro-Brussels speech on Monday, which suggested that Britain's rebate might be negotiable. Indeed, given that Britain is now a much richer country than when the rebate was first negotiated back in 1984 (Britain was the third poorest country in the EU then, but is fourth richest now), it is hard to disagree with Mandelson's suggestion that the new entrants should not have to contribute to Britain's rebate.

Yet, according to a cabinet colleague, both Blair and Straw were livid with Mandelson. It's easy to understand why they are going along with the new Labour Europe-bashing. First, the immediate reaction from Brussels to the French and Dutch referendums was absurd - just carry on, it was only the people voting, they don't matter. Next, Jacques Chirac's tactic of using the British rebate to obscure the more embarrassing and fundamental issues facing the EU was contemptible. Personal relations between Chirac and Blair have been abysmal since the Iraq war, and Chirac, like Schröder, is on the way to retirement.

So, why not sit things out, and wait for the next generation of leaders? By going off to speak to Angela Merkel, likely to be the next German chancellor, Blair has signalled that he is doing just that. Why not let the crisis continue until others see sense?

The short answer to this is that it would be a dangerous failure of leadership, even a failure of duty. Tony Blair is now a powerful leader in the EU, freshly re-elected and with a strong economy behind him. To let the British presidency slide by, the crisis unaddressed, would be shameful. Economic reform is all very well, but this crisis is about the constitution and the budget. Someone needs to start setting out a plausible road through the mess, and it should be Britain.

Before that happens we will need a dramatic change of attitude - or "mood", as Mandelson described it - in London. Britain can have no moral or political authority if we refuse to negotiate anything, even a small symbolic clipping at the side of the rebate. We do pay more than France. But there is a logic in the French position, too, never reported in the British press. France has twice our landmass, with the same number of people. It has 28m hectares of agricultural land, compared to our 16m. Their farm subsidies - our rebate: both are unsurprisingly popular at home. But Britain and France are going to have to start compromising if they value the EU.

There is a chance for Britain to lead over the next six months, but only if we speak and behave as Europeans, not only as Britons. Tony Blair used to understand that. He used to say it. But he no longer sounds as if he is interested. It is easier to fight the rest of Europe over Britain's rebate than it is to fight the anti-Europeans back home. The danger is that sabre-rattling and point-scoring could lead to a complete breakdown in the European project this weekend. Tony Blair may say he's not a Eurosceptic. But he sounds like one to me.

jackie.ashley@theguardian.com

rank_144.title: Budget delays put strain on new EU member states
rank_144.text:
Leaders in some of the EU's latest members, who joined last year as a way of shaking off the legacy of communism, are warning of severe consequences if no budget is agreed soon.

Vital projects to revive their economies will be put on hold unless Britain and France resolve their differences over EU funding, a series of ministers from eastern Europe told the Guardian yesterday.

One minister even warned that Euroscepticism, which began to wane in Poland after farm subsidies started to roll in, may return as critics seize on the budget failure.

"Discussions on the budget will have an impact on the support for membership [of the EU]," warned a Polish economy minister, Krystyna Gurbiel. "The principle of solidarity, which is one of the key principals in the union for us, seems in practice to be a bit questioned."

A new budget is so important to the 10 new countries that they offered at the 11th hour of the budget row in Brussels last week to forego millions of pounds to save the talks. This failed, leaving them with two unpalatable options:

· Under the worst case scenario, if no budget is agreed by 2007, they will be forced to remain second-class EU members. If Britain and France fail to resolve their differences by then, the new members will be denied the "full envelope" of EU payments - which is around 300% more than the amount they receive now.

· Even if the budget is agreed before 2007 - and they have another nine months if they stick to the timetable of the last round in 1999 - the new entrants will suffer. Without a budget they cannot open negotiations with Brussels on how to spend billions of pounds in structural and cohesion funds to build motorways, and regenerate deprived areas.

Mrs Gurbiel said: "It is a serious delay and it means that we shall have less time to implement the projects. We cannot start before the programmes are approved. I am afraid that if the decisions are not taken shortly, by 2007 we will not be able to continue support for enterprises very much needed in Poland."

Etele Baráth, Hungary's Europe minister, said: "It is serious. It is not just a question of money. For us it is very important to know how much, for what goal, when and what way we can use the money. It is important we are well prepared for 2007-13. It is a bit of a shock. We have lost a lot of time."

Leaders of the new EU members were furious with Britain for leading the campaign to reject the budget after Tony Blair demanded a cut in farm subsidies as the price for removing Britain's budget rebate. Marek Belka, the Polish prime minister, had Britain in mind when he criticised "national egoism", in remarks which indicated that countries historically well disposed to London may now be having second thoughts.

The ministers chose their language carefully yesterday but most made clear that Britain had behaved unreasonably, making it difficult to see how an agreement can be reached when it assumes the presidency of the EU on July 1. Ms Gurbiel said: "Questioning [farm subsidies] makes this problem very difficult. For us the CAP is very important. Our farmers are getting much lower subsidies than the farmers in the older EU member states. So we cannot agree to a solution that will hit our farmers. That is a very difficult issue for Poland."

Mr Baráth said: "It will be difficult [to agree the budget during the British presidency]. Between France and Britain there is a big gulf over CAP. That is very, very difficult ... The surprise was that in the last minutes [of the negotiations] the British opinion was much harder."

There was strong support for Britain, however, from the Czech Republic. Cyril Svobod, the Czech foreign minister, said: "In my view Tony Blair was right. Some of the reforms he suggested are highly welcome."

Britain is acutely aware of the anger in the east and will be mounting a diplomatic offensive to restore relations. British ministers will point out that workers from the new member states are allowed free access to Britain, unlike France and Germany who restrict access.

rank_208.title: Leader: Politicians and judges
rank_208.text:
Last week Tony Blair hinted that he is prepared to confront the judges to get new anti-terrorism laws on to the statute book this autumn. Yesterday Michael Howard characteristically went further, warning that "aggressive judicial activism" is preventing parliament from doing its job of passing new laws to protect the public from the kind of threats that killed so many Londoners on July 7. Between them, the prime minister and the leader of the opposition are clearly signalling a confrontation with the judiciary over individual rights in the terrorist age. The issue is set to dominate the politics of the winter and beyond.

As July 7 showed, terrorism against innocent citizens is a modern reality. Politicians are not merely entitled to respond strongly; they also have an obligation to do so. But politicians should neither exaggerate nor seek to bully the courts out of doing their job. In our politico-media culture, politicians rarely suffer for talking tough. But the courts have a fixed and proper role to play in a democracy. And citizens should beware of politicians who threaten the judges in pursuit of other agendas - which in Mr Howard's case means his Euroscepticism-drenched hostility to the 1998 Human Rights Act.

Politicians are currently fond of mocking Lord Hoffman's comment in the Belmarsh judgment - in which the law lords overturned an important part of Britain's post 9/11 anti-terror laws - to the effect that it is those laws rather than terrorism itself that constitutes the greater threat to the nation. Mr Howard quoted Lord Hoffman again in his Daily Telegraph article yesterday. The intention, obviously enough, is to show that silly old out-of-touch judges do not live in the real world where people on tube trains get blown to smithereens merely because they live, in the words of one alleged Islamo-terrorist this week, in the "vital organ of the minions of the devil"

Anyone who has actually read the Belmarsh judgment, as opposed merely to Lord Hoffman's part of it, will know that what the court said in December 2004 was much more measured and far more authoritative than this implies. In fact, though you would never know this from most of the political comment on the case, Lord Bingham's lead judgment (the one that spoke for the majority of the law lords) actually rejected Lord Hoffman's argument that there was no emergency after 9/11 sufficient to justify fresh laws. That was a matter for parliament and the government to decide, Lord Bingham insisted, and the courts should be "unintrusive", in line with European - yes, Mr Howard, European - precedent.

However, Lord Bingham then went on, courts are specialists in the protection of liberty - and have been so since long before 1998. They are fully entitled to define the legal issues raised in statutes. "The function of independent judges charged to interpret and apply the law is universally recognised as a cardinal feature of the modern democratic state, a cornerstone of the rule of law itself," said Lord Bingham. These are fine words, which could properly be carved in stone over the entrance of the new supreme court, when the building is ready.

Too many politicians, the Daily Mail breathing down their necks, feel compelled to take cheap shots at the judges. Too many lawyers, sometimes insouciant towards the realities both of the terror threat and of living with a feral media, are equally contemptuous of politicians. In this too often unedifying atmosphere of adversarial caricature, it remains for good politicians and good lawyers to hold the line, so that ministers, MPs and judges all play their proper roles in the defence of the strong and principled system of democratic government that Lord Bingham set out so authoritatively. In the making of any new terrorism law, both parliament and the judges must have their legitimate parts to play.

rank_170.title: David Clark: Britain's claim to economic superiority is built on sand
rank_170.text:
Although usually couched in terms of sovereignty and national identity, the real question at the heart of the Europe debate has always been one of political economy. Conservative opinion was comfortable with Europe when its social model was seen as a useful bulwark against Soviet influence, but turned against it in the 1980s when the party fell for the "voodoo economics" of the American new right.

Labour's journey has been more complicated. It rejected Brussels when the idea of national economic planning was still in vogue. When the dream of "socialism in one country" collapsed, Jaques Delors's vision of a social Europe was embraced as an appealing alternative to Thatcherism.

New Labour now appears to be reverting to a mild form of Euroscepticism, but this time its critique of Europe is of the right. The social market economy, once seen as a paradigm of modernity, is dismissed as an outdated failure, straining under the burden of unaffordable welfare entitlements and employment rights. A serious dose of liberal market reform is needed to enable it to compete with the more virile American business model. In other words, the rest of Europe needs to follow Britain.

This debate has come to the fore as a result of France's rejection of the European constitution, but not in the way "no" voters clearly expected. With characteristic lack of embarrassment, Tony Blair has seized on the unfolding crisis and the happy coincidence of Britain's EU presidency to push for more market liberalisation, despite the fact that this vision is precisely what the French people thought they were voting against. Next month, Blair convenes an informal summit of EU leaders to discuss the future of Europe's social model. By then he expects a rightwing government to have taken power in Germany and the balance of forces to have shifted decisively in his favour.

He is confident that Britain's recent past can be Europe's chosen future, and his favourite thinktank, the Institute for Public Policy Research, has even given his ambition a name: the Anglo-social model. This is said to combine market dynamism and social justice in a policy mix tailored to the demands of the 21st century. There is something to be said for this. The Blair era has been one of genuine progressive advance, as even his critics should admit. Unemployment has been reduced to the lowest level for 30 years, public services have been significantly improved, and pensioner and child poverty has been cut.

Even so, it would be foolish to imagine that Britain can stake a claim to the leadership of Europe on this basis. These achievements are real, but they are only impressive by British standards. In his speech to the European parliament in June, Blair was at pains to stress the socially progressive elements of his platform. But highlighting New Labour's adoption of a minimum wage has limited impact in countries that have had one for years. And on investment in public services, poverty reduction and childcare provision, Britain remains a European laggard.

To the extent that there are features of the Anglo-social model to be admired, they are ones borrowed from Europe. The active labour market and welfare-to-work policies that have created high levels of employment were pioneered by the Swedes and the Dutch. The half a million new public sector jobs is little more than catch up. The expansion of childcare - one New Labour policy with genuine transformative potential - is Scandinavian in inspiration. New rights to paid leave and limits on working time are the result of European rather than domestic legislation.

If the best features of the Anglo-social model are familiar to the Europeans who invented them, there are others that make them recoil in horror. Britain remains one of the most socially divided countries in Europe, with levels of inequality closer to America than much of the continent. And although the gap between rich and poor has narrowed in the past couple of years, it has only just returned the levels inherited from the Conservatives. This is a record to be ashamed of.

Much of Britain's claim to economic superiority is built on sand. The secret of our success on jobs and growth has been the extraordinary accumulation of private debt and a consumer splurge that has boosted the service sector. A buy now, pay later economy is fine provided tomorrow never comes. Unfortunately, it always does. When that moment arrives and the low-paid service jobs dry up, Britain's relative weakness in exports, manufacturing and productivity compared with Europe will become painfully apparent. Indeed, there are already indications in falling unemployment, rising profitability and the best export performance in the world that the German economy is at last on the move. If so, it may not be too long before the eurozone is outperforming Britain.

None of this is to deny that there are problems with the European social model or that Britain can play a constructive role in helping to solve them. Germans consumers in particular need to spend more freely, albeit without accumulating British debt levels. Like Britain, the main continental economies need to devote more effort to creating new jobs than to protecting old ones. But they should also care about the quality of those jobs. It is still the case that it is often better to be unemployed in Germany than on minimum wage in Britain. This is not something New Labour should feel smug about.

If there is a model that provides the optimum mix of economic dynamism and social justice for Europe to succeed, it is not the Anglo-social or Rhineland ones. As Robert Taylor argues in a forthcoming pamphlet for Compass, it is to be found in Scandinavia - and Sweden in particular. In recent years, the Swedes have combined healthy growth, low unemployment, rising productivity and large export surpluses with some of the lowest levels of inequality in the world. Moreover, a strong welfare state and a framework of social bargaining that involves the trade unions are the mechanisms through which they have managed economic change successfully. According to neo-liberal orthodoxy, these are the very things that are supposed to be holding Europe back.

To be fair, those who coined the term Anglo-social model concede that it is a work in progress and that its success will depend on it continuing to move in a more Scandinavian direction. But New Labour ministers are rarely so modest. According to them, Britain is already an exemplar for Europe to follow. By being more humble in acknowledging its political debt to Europe, the government would not only be more likely to get a hearing in Brussels; it might also help to restore the idea that Europe is Britain's natural home.

· David Clark is a former Labour government adviser and a senior research fellow at the Federal Trust

dkclark@aol.com

rank_284.title: John Monks: Europe is all we've got
rank_284.text:
Has a large part of the British trade union movement lost faith in Europe? As TUC affiliates prepare for their annual congress in Brighton, a new mood of Euroscepticism seems to have seized some sections of the movement.

In the run-up to the failed constitutional referendums in France and the Netherlands earlier this year, some British trade unionists were claiming that the European constitution comprised "an aggressive attack on working people", and that the European commission is an "overwhelmingly rightwing body" committed to "Thatcherism and militarisation".

That is not true, and there is a danger of British trade unions working in their own worst interests if they once again paint the EU as the tool of unbridled capitalism.

True, motions before next week's congress are couched in more moderate terms. One of them "rejects" the existing EU constitution and "increasingly neo-liberal policies emanating from Brussels". But other unions are more positive, putting pressure on the UK presidency to give stronger backing to the "European social model", and highlighting the crucial challenge of developing EU-wide trade union solidarity in response to the rapid trend towards cross-border businesses and services.

The European Trade Union Confederation works with the commission in drawing up social policy. That doesn't mean to say we always agree - and indeed the ETUC shares many of the concerns of British trade unions about existing legislative proposals. We are currently fighting with every means available - including the support of MEPs in the European parliament - to end the UK's opt-out from the already flexible working time directive. Equally unpopular was the Commission's botched draft Directive for liberalising services in the internal market. But the ETUC brought 75,000 trade unionists onto the streets of Brussels in March to declare their opposition, and since then the proposal has gone back to the drawing board.

However, we supported the constitution - with reservations - as a necessary tool for strengthening social rights and moving Europe forward. The referendum outcomes, leaving the EU in a state of limbo, were misguidedly acclaimed by some as a victory for the left. Yet many sections of the British business community and media seized on the no votes to push forward their so-called "reform" agenda of deregulation, enfeebled worker protection and an EU reduced to the status of a free-trade zone.

Since the abortive June summit and the launch of the UK presidency, Tony Blair has made EU reform his call to arms. But recent studies have shown that Europe's economic performance is by no means as far behind the US as some would have us believe, and that the UK's market-oriented reform model, based as it is on a buoyant property market, is not so sustainable after all.

Yet there is a real danger that the planned EU social model debate this autumn will strengthen calls for widespread deregulation and cuts in social spending, mimicking US policies. In response, the ETUC is set to launch its own campaign for a strong European social dimension that individual citizens can actually relate to.

The EU supports a model of social partnership - cooperation between employers and workers - that must be the way forward for modern economies. Legislation on workers' information and consultation, and the setting up of European works councils in cross-border firms, offer the main chance for employees to have a say in multinational company policies - crucial when it comes to restructuring. But the rules need to be stronger.

In the long term, Europe cannot resist the trends of globalisation, and the recent "bra mountain" furore has highlighted how fast traditional manufacturing industries like textiles are moving to China and other developing countries. But it can - and must - help its citizens to deal with them, through investment in training, lifelong learning and policies that really put into practice its commitment to better jobs in a high-skill, knowledge economy.

In these areas, single nations acting alone can have little influence. Economic muscle makes the difference, and when they speak with one voice, the 25 EU member states have the power to bring about change. At present, Europe is the only model on offer of a developed society that aims to couple growth with boosting the wellbeing of its citizens. But without the engagement of a vigilant but positive trade union movement pushing for the interests of working people, that model could be at risk.

· John Monks is general secretary of the European Trade Union Confederation

rank_173.title: William Keegan: Europe needs to do some fiscal jerks
rank_173.text:
The late Hugo Young once told me he had a theory about Tony Blair. It was that our Labour Prime Minister was obsessed with money and the high life, and in an ideal world would in due course like to move on to become chairman of News International.

That would have been after fulfilling his ambition of establishing Britain's position 'at the very heart of Europe' by putting the pound into the eurozone. Young, the distinguished Guardian columnist, was passionately keen on the euro, as, for a time, was Blair. Older readers will recall that, although I myself have always been a strong believer in 'Europe', this belief did not stretch to joining the euro, a standpoint which upset Young and others.

This position was founded, and still is, not on euroscepticism (I love the way Ted Heath used to pronounce the word as 'euro-septics'), but on distrust of the pre-Keynesian rules according to which macro-economic policy is conducted in the eurozone.

We now know that Rupert Murdoch had the right of first refusal with regard to Blair's European policy. I happen to think that Murdoch's reservations about the euro were well based, but it is unlikely that his feelings about European economic policy are the first consideration in his anti-Europeanism. It was also outrageous if, as widely reported, in calling for a referendum on the Constitutional Treaty Blair was primarily influenced by Murdoch.

Blair's move forced President Chirac into a corner and, instead of regarding the treaty as a necessary tidying-up exercise to streamline the functioning of an enlarged European Union, the French turned it into a vote about Chirac himself, unemployment, 'neo-liberalism' and other issues. One message from the voters was: 'There may be problems with the economy, but we don't want to jettison the European social model.'

A similar message has emerged from the German election. There is economic discontent - not surprisingly with unemployment so high, especially in the east - but there is no great appetite for Angela Merkel's brand of higher taxes, greater cuts in social benefits than already envisaged, and a 'flat tax' that will exacerbate social tension.

To read most of the reactions to the German result, one would think the economy was on its uppers. Yet the truth is that it has proved remarkably resilient in the face of two severe shocks to the system, shocks in which politics has triumphed over economics.

At this stage we need a brief detour to the strategy Gordon Brown and his left-hand man, Ed Balls, devised towards the euro, in the face of huge pressure. Brown became Chancellor 24 years after Heath had taken Britain into the European Community. Apart from the political considerations, which were powerful, policy-makers at the time were also convinced that there were strong economic reasons for our joining a wider market and subjecting British industry to what it was hoped would be beneficial competitive pressures.

Such considerations also affected Margaret Thatcher's attitude when she signed the Single European Act of 1986.

But when it came to Brown's Chancellorship in 1997, the British economy seemed to have done reasonably well under Kenneth Clarke's stewardship, whereas Germany was wrestling with the economic difficulties of unification, and it was obvious that the rules of the macro-economic game in the prospective eurozone (formed in 1999) were far from attractive. Moreover, we must never forget the legacy of the searing experience of our ill-fated adventure in the exchange rate mechanism in 1990-92.

Now, from its inception the 'common market' put politics above economics, but for a good reason - one of which I am sure Brown would have approved. Economic ties would bring France and Germany closer in a way that would make another war between them unthinkable. The strategy was a resounding success.

But the German economy's current problems stem from two subsequent episodes when politics once again triumphed over economics. The first was the manner in which unification took place after the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989 (Karl-Otto Poehl, the president of the Bundesbank, resigned over the one-for-one exchange rate between West and East Germany on which Chancellor Helmut Kohl insisted). West German officials discovered that, in the words of one, much of East Germany was 'an economic junk heap'. And then East German wage levels were allowed to rise much too fast towards western levels. The result was that the German economy, especially in the east, faced a huge competitiveness problem.

The next, and closely related, example of politics triumphing over economics was the way long-term plans for the formation of the eurozone were brought forward at the insistence of France's President Mitterrand and others, who feared the 'economic might' of a united Germany and wished for a European Germany rather than a German Europe.

This wish for a European Germany was shared by Kohl and the German establishment. I hasten to add that I'm not questioning the historical vision, merely noting the economic consequences. The consequences were the formation of the European Central Bank, and the strict fiscal rules of the Stability and Growth Pact.

The combination, as pointed out many times in this column, produced a restrictive macro-economic framework, which did not help a former West Germany that was now transferring some 4.5 per cent of its gross domestic product each year to the east - and still is.

There are several ironies. The strict economic framework was insisted upon by the Germans themselves, out of concern for the supposed laxity of the countries they christened 'the club Med' (Spain, Italy, Portugal and Greece). The German economy was hoist by its own petard.

Despite all this, the German economy is fundamentally in better shape than one is often given to believe. When the conventional view is that there has been precious little reform, German employers and the labour force have between them reduced unit costs and improved competitiveness dramatically. Germany is the world's leading exporter and, for all the moaning about 'outsourcing to China', business investment within Germany has been increasing for some time.

The traditional sequence of events during a German recovery was for higher exports to induce more investment and this in turn to encourage greater consumer spending. But the mood is bad and the economic problem in Germany is one of poor domestic demand and high savings.

Germany has a vast balance of payments surplus. Inflation expectations are low. If the spirit of Lord Keynes were to descend on Berlin this weekend, he would say: 'Come on, get moving. Forget the conventional Bundesbank wisdom, which would consider raising interest rates because of fears of inflation even at a time like this. Expand demand, and deal with pensions, health costs and other demographic concerns when you have the economy back on its feet.'

The International Monetary Fund's director of research, Raghuram Rajan, said last week: 'Europe's citizens do not seem convinced that the bitter medicine of continued structural reforms will cure the stasis that afflicts much of the continent.'

Too right they don't. They need lower interest rates and fiscal expansion (lower taxes, higher government spending) to get the European economy moving. Then they might be in better shape to face 'reforms'. Remember the horrors of the early Thatcher period, which made unemployment much worse before things got better.

If private savings are too high and restricting domestic demand, it is crazy for governments to add to the deflationary pressure with further cuts.

Nothing less is required than a complete rethink of economic policy at ministerial and central banking level in Europe. There must be a better way, and the French and German electorates sense this.

rank_92.title: Say hello to Mr Camerair
rank_92.text:
Question: what's the difference between David Cameron and Tony Blair? Answer: 13 years. Every upbeat, feelgood word that Cameron utters, every media-savvy move that his spin doctors make, is testament to the way that Blair has transformed British politics - as much in his decade as Margaret Thatcher did in hers. And the content is quite similar too: New Blair with added Euroscepticism. Welcome to the age of Mr Camerair.

Take that inspiring Conservative party conference speech with which David Cameron launched himself like a rocket from Cape Canaveral. I've spent a fair bit of time over the past few years reading Blair speeches. They have an unmistakeable look on the page:

Very short sentences.

Large gaps between each line.

I care passionately about this. We must do that.

Self-deprecating joke. Guy-on-the-street anecdote.

List of past failures. Visions of future success! Sentences without verbs.

Now I download Cameron's conference speech from his zippy website and, yes, it's a Blair. It has exactly the same look on the page, the same syntax of exhortation. Cameron speaks like a thoroughly modern private school headmaster, giving the boys a pep talk. Like Blair, he's not afraid of the word "I", nor of going over the top in missionary mode: "I love my country. I love our character. I love our people, our history, our role in the world." He, too, can make the higher nonsense sound like sense: "The Conservative party is the only party that wants everybody to be a somebody, a doer not a done-for." Hang on, so who exactly do Labour and the Lib Dems want to be a nobody? Never mind, it makes the audience feel good, a purpose he frankly confesses two sentences later: "I want people to feel good about being a Conservative again."

Then there's the characteristic Blair shock-list of statistics: "When one-fifth of children leave primary school unable to write properly. When 1 million schoolchildren play truant each year." And so on. The verb-to-sentence ratio is slightly higher than in early Blair, but here again are the verbless wonders. "To give choice to parents. Freedom to schools." This follows a passage about raising standards of literacy. (New Tories, new grammar: "No, Belinda, a sentence does not need to have a subject, a verb and an object. A sentence needs a subject, an object and a spin.") And his heart bleeds on his sleeve for Darfur and sub-Saharan Africa. At the end comes the rebranding: Modern Compassionate Conservatism, all with initial capitals. Or MCC for short.

What's true of the style is also true of the content. His Policy Programme, Blairishly entitled Vision for Britain, contains this remarkable assertion: "We must be a party committed to a vast programme of public service improvement." Vast. Is this Franklin Delano Roosevelt's New Deal or William Beveridge's ambitious wartime plans for the welfare state? No, it's post-Blair public service hyperbole. And there's a touch of matricide too, as Cameron rejects one of Thatcher's most famous assertions. "There is such a thing as society," he says, adding catchily but emptily, "It's just not the same thing as the state." Well, d'oh! You don't say.

There are differences in emphasis, some of his emphases being more liberal than current government policy. For example, measures against terrorism "must never undermine the very liberal values we're seeking to preserve. So, no ID cards, no religious hatred laws that impinge on free speech." Other parts are less liberal. But there is nothing here that Blair could not sign on to if he and Cameron were compelled to form a Grand Coalition, as their German counterparts just have. In the 1950s wits called it Butskellism, the centrist political consensus identified by the Economist with an imaginary Mr Butskell, combining the names of the Tory chancellor Rab Butler and Labour's Hugh Gaitskell. For today's crossbreed of Blair and Cameron, the New Statesman has got there before me, entitling a piece by the sharp-penned Nick Cohen "The birth of Blameron". I prefer my version, Camerair, since it also hints at the essential mixture of television cameras and hot air. It's so characteristic that Cameron's years of experience in the "real world" of business were actually in a media company, namely, Carlton Communications.

Camerairism reflects a structural change more profound than Butskellism ever did. After the great ideological struggles of the 20th century, when communism and fascism were serious competitors to more or less liberal democracy, politics in most advanced industrial democracies is no longer about systemic alternatives. It's about variants of democratic capitalism. In Britain, in particular, it's more like a competition between two rival management teams, trying to convince shareholders that they are best suited to run UK plc. After NLNB (New Labour, New Britain), here's a bid from MCC.

Camerairism also invites us to reflect on the resilience of the ruling classes. If Cameron gets the job, both major parties will - until Blair's promised departure - be run by upper middle-class public schoolboys, many of whose close advisers share similar privileged backgrounds. Only in France do you have a comparable phenomenon, based on many of the same elements: a very elitist top end of the educational ladder, a metropolitan political culture, and, above all, a system of individually but not collectively removable inequalities, which allows the governing class constantly to replenish itself with new blood.

For all that modern-man-of-the-people stuff, Cameron is an authentic toff: a product of Eton and Oxford, self-deprecatingly explaining that he only belongs to the exclusive, socially conservative White's club in St James's because his father, a retired stockbroker, was chairman of it. Even his youthful experimentation with cannabis or cocaine, if that is what his professed "mistakes" comprised, fits this picture. His spliff, if spliff it was, was a toff spliff.
