That's the spliff with added ambition, like the one I recall a future foreign leader passing to me at a student party at Exeter College, Oxford, while canvassing my vote in an effort to be elected president of the Oxford Union debating society.

Watching the Blairites getting used to the trappings and privileges of power, the chauffeured limousines, the parties, the Derry Irvine wallpaper and themselves in time graciously assenting to become Lords and Ladies, I have often thought of Hilaire Belloc's lines:

The accursed power which stands on Privilege (And goes with Women, and Champagne, and Bridge)

Broke - and Democracy resumed her reign: (Which goes with Bridge, and Women and Champagne).

With the Cameronites, you can be sure it will be the same only more so. "The new comes back", as an old east European saying has it. MCC stands for Modern Compassionate Conservatism. It's also the acronym of one of England's most tradition-conscious cricket clubs. Old and new are artfully combined. "Things must change, so they remain the same," says Lampedusa's old Sicilian prince.

Of course all my speculation may be void in a few weeks' time, should the Conservative rank-and-file prefer David Davis to David Cameron. But if they want a serious chance of returning to power, they'll go for Mr Camerair.

Illustration: Matt Kenyon

rank_256.title: Obituary: Sir Roy Denman
rank_256.text:
Sir Roy Denman, who has died aged 81, was one of the senior civil servants who negotiated the details of Britain's entry into the European Common Market in the early 1970s. He went on to work for the European commission in Brussels, and latterly in Washington as its ambassador to the US. His experiences made him an articulate champion of European integration and a trenchant critic of Euroscepticism, particularly as tepidly practised by successive British governments.

Unusually for one who retired from the pinnacles of both British and EU bureaucracy, Denman did not just decline into agreeable retirement. Instead, he carried on the fight to make the British love Europe - or at least see where their national interest lay in becoming more enthusiastic about it. In pursuit of the case, he wrote two pugnacious but elegant books, regular letters to the press and articles for publications as diverse as the Guardian, the Wall Street Journal and the New York Herald Tribune.

He also maintained an apartment in Brussels (as well as one in central London) to which he and his wife would repair for at least one week a month to catch up on the news and gossip. Brussels-based journalists (of whom I was one) would receive regular summonses to lunch in his favourite restaurant, at his expense, for a leisurely exchange of views. It was usually a worthwhile, as well as convivial, experience. Genial, unstuffy and entirely lacking in snobbery or condescension, Denman was well worth listening to, not least when he accurately (and scornfully) predicted early on that, for all the Blair government's pro-European rhetoric, the prime minister lacked the nerve to make hard choices and become a leader in the EU.

Denman was born in Liverpool, the son of a post office engineer and grandson of a docker. His father's career took the family to London, and the son was educated at Harrow grammar school. There he fell under the spell of an inspirational teacher of German, a language in which he became fluent and which formed the basis for a lifelong admiration of Germany and its people. He won a scholarship to read modern languages at St John's College, Cambridge, and completed a year of the course before being called up in 1942 to join the Royal Signals, which posted him to India. He served in the Burma campaign with the Gurkhas and ended the war as a major at the age of 21.

Back at Cambridge he took a first and applied to the civil service. Turned down by the Foreign Office, allegedly because he did not have a public school background, he started in the Board of Trade, working his way up in a couple of years from the equivalent of a junior clerk's job to an assistant private secretary to the president, as the departmental minister was then known.

In his memoirs, The Mandarin's Tale (2002), Denman recalled an unexpected encounter with the ageing prime minister, Winston Churchill: "He looked as though he had just woken up from a post-prandial sleep and did not seem in the best of tempers. Gazing at me with evident distaste, he inquired grumpily and loudly, 'Who's he?' The great man was then pretty deaf. 'THE PRESIDENT OF THE BOARD OF TRADE'S PRIVATE SECRETARY'. 'Huh,' said Churchill scornfully, 'Tell him to bugger off.' I did."

In the mid-1950s, Denman was posted to the British embassy in Bonn to promote trade interests; he found that the ambassador and most of the diplomatic staff could not speak the language and despised the erstwhile enemy. But it was here that he began to discover his true vocation as a diplomat and trade negotiator, skills honed as he moved on to become counsellor to the British delegation at trade negotiations in Geneva and then part of the high-ranking team working through the small print of the European treaty for several arduous years before British entry in 1973.

He returned to London to become the Cabinet Office coordinator for European affairs, but became increasingly disillusioned and frustrated during the Wilson government's laborious, and largely bogus, renegotiation of the treaty on which he had worked so hard. As his memoirs make clear, he viewed some ministers of the period with thinly veiled contempt, and when the opportunity arose in 1977 he moved to the commission as director-general for external affairs. It was a hugely unusual move for a Whitehall permanent secretary, especially at a time when the British government often sent second-raters to Brussels, a shortsightedness which only exacerbated British lack of influence.

Denman spent the next five years travelling the world negotiating trade agreements for the EU, and finished his career in Reagan-era Washington (1982-89), convincing the administration of the efficacy of a more united continent.

He devoted a vigorous retirement to arguing the case for a fuller and more enthusiastic British engagement in Europe, especially in his book Missed Chances, Britain and Europe in the 20th Century (1996), whose title summarised his thesis. No one could accuse him of being a cloudy-headed romantic, or lacking experience in real-politik, but it was, nevertheless, a frustrating, aggravating and doubtless dispiriting experience for someone who had devoted his career to public service and the European ideal.

Denman married Maya Lade in 1966. The couple had a son and a daughter.

Christopher Roberts, UK director-general for trade policy (1987-97), writes: Roy Denman exercised considerable personal influence in two key areas of Bristish and European policy - Britain's relations with the EU and liberalisation of international trade. He played a central role in the various negotiations for Bristish membership of the European Community from the late 1950s onwards, but neither then, nor in his later jobs, was he an uncritical admirer of European institutions. As one of the first British directors-general to join the commission, he was able to temper some of its continental traditions with a more pragmatic British approach to public administration.

Throughout his life he remained an eloquent advocate of European integration, and of the need for Britain to be fully committed to Europe. This was his view as a young man, when the cause was seen by many as progressive and forward-looking. It remained his view into old age, when he would restate firmly held opinions against opponents and fainthearts from any background.

At a time when the developed countries dominated international trade negotiations, Roy, with his tall and imposing figure and command of languages, was recognised as a key player, first in the British team in the Gatt Kennedy round negotiations of the mid-1960s, and 15 years later as the EU senior trade negotiator. In the former role certainly, and in the latter role as far as particular vested interests would allow, he contributed much to the freeing up of world trade, and thus to increasing global prosperity in the late 20th century.

Roy was no respecter of persons. To his credit, the objects of his witty and sharp turns of phrase were usually his seniors, including ministers and commissioners. But after enjoying his sallies at the expense of others, you could also feel that the quarry of his next shaft of wit, once you were round the corner, might well be yourself. With his passing, the world will be a greyer place.

· Roy Denman, civil servant and diplomat, born June 12 1924; died April 4 2006

rank_161.title: Blair's dangerous duvet days
rank_161.text:
As post-Blair politics takes shape, what new policy can Labour craft on Europe? The initial news last Friday morning that Downing Street was to appoint a secretary of state for Europe would have transformed British politics.

First, it would have sent a clear signal to a leaderless Europe that Britain was prepared for a new role in the EU. Second, it would have obliged David Cameron to appoint a shadow cabinet member for Europe to deal with questions in the Commons - an appointment that would expose the enduring Euroscepticism deep in the Tory soul. And third, it would have finally forced Whitehall to take the EU seriously and move from defensive diplomacy to seeing Europe as the place where 21st-century Britain needs to be a commanding player.

Alas, Whitehall traditionalism and prime ministerial caution rose up to snuff out this bold, reforming proposal before it ever became reality. It is not a question of personalities: despite starting life in the camp opposed the then European Community, Robin Cook and Jack Straw dealt with Europe in a calm, professional manner quite different from the hysterical hostilities unleashed in the 1990s by the Major administration, and Margaret Beckett will maintain the steady pro-European line put in place by Tony Blair after 1997.

This line has served Britain well and made London the favourite EU capital for new European nations as well as for many politicians from older EU member states, who come to Britain to see whether Labour has found the philosopher's stone of strong market economics combined with massive investment in social justice.

Moreover, Ms Beckett has more international negotiating experience under her belt than most new foreign secretaries, from her days at the Department of Trade and Industry, where she tenaciously defended the Kyoto treaty against US efforts to sabotage it.

But her red box will be full of many real-time problems, of which Iran, Iraq and Hamas are the most obvious. Latin America is a continent undergoing seismic political movement, but no Labour foreign secretary has been there since 1997. Ditto Australia, where a reformed Labour party is sniffing at ousting the eternal John Howard.

Britain lags behind other major powers in the very few trips its foreign policy chief makes to the new quintet of Asian powers: China, Japan, Korea, Vietnam and India. These cultures are based on personal contacts and relations, and if Britain is absent, it is noticed. So the new foreign secretary will have plenty to do. The kind of attention to Europe that was on offer when Harold Macmillan and Edward Heath made European affairs a full-time cabinet post will not be there.

This is a shame, as the politics of Europe, both at home and in the EU, are undergoing fundamental change. In Britain, the decision of a group of Conservative MPs to come out for full withdrawal from the EU shows how the isolationist politics shared by Ukip and the BNP are infecting the Conservative party. No less a conservative figure than the Republican senator John McCain, the possible replacement for George Bush, has publicly rebuked David Cameron for his snubbing of links with European rightwingers like Angela Merkel and Nicholas Sarkozy.

For most in Britain, the arcane politics of the European People's party, the umbrella grouping of the EU's conservative parties, is pure anorak territory; but in Europe's capitals, Cameron's fellow rightwing leaders are openly critical of the new Tory leader's extremist line on cooperation in Europe.

For Labour, it is time to make more public the deep blue water that divides the Tory politics of rejectionism on Europe from Labour and the Lib-Dems, who both see Europe in positive terms. The old rows over Europe in Britain are dying down; euro-entry is not on the agenda for the foreseeable future. When I made this observation as Europe minister 18 months ago, there was press agitation, but getting worked up about the euro is yesterday's story. Similarly, the constitution is dead. To be sure, Europe will need new arrangements by 2009 to take account of further enlargement, and parliaments can adopt and pass a simple intergovernmental agreement to have a standing chair of the European council. But the great constitutional moment, as shaped by Valéry Giscard d'Estaing, is over.

At the same time, there are signs of a lift-off for the European economy, mainly based on countries like Spain, the east European nations, Ireland and parts of the German economy, which are putting in place the reforms the Blair-Brown administration has shown to have worked in Britain. Trade unions, under the subtle leadership of John Monks, the head of the European Trade Union Confederation, are seeking to write a new text for social Europe: the old Delors social Europe vision belonged to a Europe of the 1980s that was not exposed to globalisation, the end of communism, or the shift to low-wage production of goods and services far away from Europe.

In a thoughtful speech yesterday to the Labour Movement for Europe, Frances O'Grady, the TUC deputy general secretary, outlined some of the new parameters to ensure that EU developments include the interests of workers. If they do not, the old European white working class will turn to the nationalist, protectionist politics on offer from Jean-Marie Le Pen and his friends in the BNP, and other similar parties.

It is tempting to think Europe can go away and not be an issue in British politics, to pull the national duvet over our heads and think only of the US or the far east as the new international frontier for Britain; tempting, but wrong. Britain needs a coherent policy for the new Europe. If Labour does not shape one, then other forces, forces deeply hostile to Europe, will.

· Denis MacShane is Labour MP for Rotherham and was the longest serving minister for Europe in Tony Blair's government

rank_303.title: Give EU more power to tackle climate change, says Balls
rank_303.text:
Gordon Brown's right hand man, Ed Balls, will say today that it is in the UK's national interest to collaborate more closely with the EU and that Brussels should have more powers to deal with issues such as climate change and the single market.

The economic secretary to the Treasury, whose views are likely to reflect those of the chancellor, will say that a stronger Europe is one of the four great areas where Britain needs to go further over the next 10 years.

"On the economy, the social dimension, the environment, enlargement and foreign policy, Europe is going to play a bigger role in the future," he told the Guardian yesterday.

"On these issues, it is in the British national interest to collaborate in a closer way in Europe in the future."

Mr Balls's intervention will be closely noted in European capitals anxious that Mr Brown's opposition to British membership of the euro and harmonised tax policies presages a deeper Euroscepticism if he takes over at No 10. Paris and Berlin are eager to understand the principles of a British foreign policy under Mr Brown, especially his attitude to the EU. Mr Balls was one of the most influential figures in the British decision not to join the euro.

His remarks, in a Fabian lecture, come as tensions over the government's European policies are growing in the Foreign Office. The foreign secretary, Margaret Beckett, barred the pro-European Europe minister, Geoff Hoon, from answering Commons questions on Europe. He was told he could answer questions on northern Uganda, even though he reports directly to the prime minister on Europe.

Mr Balls will argue that the EU is vital to forming the stepping stone to a worldwide carbon trading scheme, and therefore the EU is a vital institution with which Britain must be positively engaged.

He told the Guardian he was quite prepared to see the EU given stronger powers to enforce an effective emissions trading scheme within the EU, including giving the commission new powers over allocating permits to pollute between nations. The current EU trading scheme has been hampered by individual countries being too generous in allocating permits to their industries.

Mr Balls, likely to be a key figure in setting the strategy for the next general election, also sees Europe and the environment as a central dividing line with the Tories. He said: "A policy of positive European engagement with our European partners is a critical stepping stone to combating climate change. It is only by being fully engaged at the European level that we will be able to do that."

He argued that it is impossible to be an environmentalist without being an internationalist, arguing the Euroscepticism of the Tories precludes Mr Cameron's party from having any serious influence over the framing of effective international action to fight climate change.

rank_166.title: Cameron's Euroscepticism may damage Tories' green ambitions
rank_166.text:
A multi-coloured papier-mache bird will have - excuse the pun - a bird's eye view of a rare sight today.

The friendly fellow, who takes pride of place in Peter Mandelson's grand office, will witness the highlight of David Cameron's visit to Brussels when the Tory leader calls on Britain's European trade commissioner.

Both men, who have met before, admire each other greatly even though they are on either sides of the political divide, if only in a technical sense.

Mr Cameron believes that Mr Mandelson was instrumental in establishing New Labour by marking out political territory which the Tories are now trying to capture.

This is why Mr Cameron is happy to describe himself as the heir to Blair in deliberate contrast to Gordon Brown who has not managed to meet Mr Mandelson since he took charge of Europe's trade negotiations more than two years ago.

For his part, Mr Mandelson believes the Tory leader is a significant political force who is aping many of the tactics he himself used in saving the Labour party.

But when the two men sit down in Mr Mandelson's large office high in the European commission's Berlaymont headquarters they will eye each other warily, because they have diametrically opposing views on the matter in hand today: Britain's place in Europe.

Mr Mandelson is a passionate supporter of Britain's membership of the EU, which he believes is leaning Britain's way under a reforming European commission.

Mr Cameron is a staunch Eurosceptic who has never fully recovered from Black Wednesday in 1992 when, as Norman Lamont's special adviser, he watched Britain's humiliating exit from the European exchange rate mechanism.

But the Tory leader's views on Europe are becoming more moderate for two reasons.

First, Mr Cameron was badly burnt by his botched attempt to take his party's MEPs out of the centre right EPP-ED group in the European parliament.

Second, some of his core political aims, such as dealing with climate change, can only be tackled with the help of the EU.

Mr Cameron will highlight this constructive approach today when he visits an "eco-house" in the EU's European district and pays a visit on José Manuel Barroso, the president of the European commission.

Mr Barroso is taking a keen interest in Mr Cameron, who may well be prime minister in 2009 when the commission's president's term of office will be up for renewal.

But Mr Barroso, who met Mr Cameron in London in October, will have a stern message for the Tory leader as he urges him to engage with Europe.

Mr Cameron will not roll over and express unquestioning admiration for Mr Barroso and the EU.

But he will not deliver a William Hague-style lecture on the need to repatriate powers back to Britain.

He will instead cast the Tories as the "champions for real change in Europe" as he warns that the EU is holding back progress in areas dear to his heart.

These are poverty in Africa - which he will say is being exacerbated by the EU's common agricultural policy - and climate change, where many EU countries are failing to live up to their Kyoto targets.

While he will be critical of the EU, the mere presence of Mr Cameron at the headquarters of the European commission will mark him out from his immediate predecessors.

Senior Tory sources say that Mr Cameron is not abandoning his strong Euroscepticism.

But he believes that if he is to present himself as a future prime minister he has no choice but to show that he will engage with the EU.

This explains why Mr Cameron has quietly dropped the Hague-era plans to renegotiate the common fisheries policy. Labour is watching Mr Cameron's evolution on Europe closely because ministers believe that some of his core policies - on climate change and confronting terrorism - will have no credibility unless he wins friends in Europe.

Charles Clarke, the pro-European former home secretary, outlined this view when he told the Guardian: "You can't be a green British prime minister without being pro-European. You can't be pro-security without being pro-European."

Mr Clarke claimed that unless Mr Cameron got his relationship with Europe "into the right place", he would not be able to contest Labour's "central propositions" on the subject.

"He probably understands that," Mr Clarke added, "though quite how he does it given his own inclinations, God only knows.

"From his domestic political point of view he has got to get his relationship with Europe in the right place and it is in a very wrong place now."

But pro-Europeans in the Labour party know that they have to be careful about delivering lectures to the Tories on Europe because Tony Blair has struggled to live up to his commitment to place Britain at the heart of Europe.

Labour, like Mr Cameron, also knows that Europe may take a new direction next year when France elects a new president and Gordon Brown becomes prime minister. Mr Clarke, who criticised Mr Blair's record on Europe in his Guardian interview in Brussels, said: "You have a major change coming through which is the new French election, with both Ségolène Royale [the Socialist candidate] and Nicolas Sarkozy [the frontrunner for the centre-right nomination] offering a more modern, more optimistic chance of leadership of France from the sclerotic leadership of Jacques Chirac.

"You then have a German presidency [of the EU] starting in January which is trying to get the EU train back on the track and make it [keep] going.

"And then you have the change in our own leadership in the UK some time in the first half of next year.

"So you have all this change happening. What will it mean and where will it go?"

Speaking at a conference on the future of Europe, Mr Clarke said he believed that the next generation of European leaders had to place security at the heart of the EU's work.

"Serious and organised crime, people trafficking, drug dealing, counter-terrorism, illegal migration: you can't sort [these] out in one country.

"You can only sort out in the EU as a whole.

"So for Britain ever-stronger defences of the white cliffs of Dover and ever-more splendid isolation won't be enough." Mr Cameron appears to be happy to look beyond Dover to meet such fundamental challenges.

But next year could be tricky for him because the Germans are due to draw up plans to revive the EU constitution, a process guaranteed to upset Eurosceptic Tories.

rank_147.title: Mick Fletcher on changes to LSC funding
rank_147.text:
It is unusual for the government to keep quiet about a good news story these days. So it's surprising that they are not shouting from the rooftops about the latest report on the tremendous benefits of European funding.

This money is being used to great effect. It is valued by the educational and training organisations that spend it. It is equally appreciated by those running the Learning and Skills Council (LSC) because it significantly helps them to meet their targets.

So why no headlines? Is this unusual reticence a late outbreak of Euroscepticism in the Department for Education and Skills?

More realistically, does the DfES fear that the imminent shrinking in European funds, an inevitable result of enlargement, will mean further cuts to the already damaged fabric of adult further education?

Or could it be that praising the flexibility of European funding and stressing its achievements risks underlining how straitjacketed the funding for mainstream adult FE has now become?

In recent years the LSC, as a co-financing agency, has handled annually between £150m and £200m of European funding, mainly from the European Social Fund (ESF). Around a fifth of the money has contributed to programmes concerned with employer engagement. Just under a fifth has been focused on work with Neets (those not in education, employment or training) and a similar sum on adult basic skills.

A report that I co-authored with Gordon Kirk for the Learning and Skills Development Agency shows that while ESF money is not used directly to deliver LSC targets, it has a substantial indirect effect. Success can be demonstrated in terms of qualifications gained as well as the participation of marginal groups.

It is more than just the sum of money that matters; £200m is not a large amount in terms of the LSC's £6bn budget, though it is an increasingly large proportion of expenditure on adult learning.

ESF, however, appears to reach the parts that mainstream funding cannot. Time and again those Kirk and I spoke to referred to the benefit of ESF in terms of its being "more flexible" than mainstream funding. An important part of the report was to unpick what this greater flexibility meant.

First, ESF funds are not tied so closely to learner numbers and volumes of qualifications. Local offices have been able to use ESF to fund the foundations on which subsequent, more target-focused work can build. Thus in many areas there was a significant investment in developing employer links, not constrained by the student number targets on which college funding rigidly depends.

Second, funding is not tied to the same short-term performance targets. So as the LSC sought to drive up performance on entry to employment (E2E) by focusing attention on the need to increase the numbers achieving in 22 weeks, and providers inevitably responded by dropping some of their more challenging clients, ESF stepped into the gap, helping to fund a raft of pre-E2E programmes.

Sometimes flexibility simply meant provision that is inevitably more expensive than average could be properly resourced. Among the examples that came up repeatedly was outreach work. ESF provision allowed adult basic skills work, and priority activity with Neet clients, to proceed.

The only negative element identified in the report is the limited impact that ESF-funded programmes are having on modifying mainstream provision.

Local staff across the country were concerned at the temporary nature of ESF funding and were anxious to protect the valuable work it had supported. Almost always, however, the response was to search for some other funding source, not to plan how the same benefits could be derived from the mainstream funding route.

We have to ask why, and whether we can't organise our mainstream funds to have some of the same flexibility that appears to underlie the success of ESF.

· Mick Fletcher is an education consultant

rank_120.title: Our Germania
rank_120.text:
Fans of France's recently elected president, Nicolas Sarkozy, should pay more attention. What was the first thing he did after being given the nuclear codes? Why, he flew off to Berlin to kiss hands with Angela Merkel, who is Chancellor of Germany - and also supreme ruler of France. When will people grasp what the European Union is all about?

So wrote Peter Hitchens in a recent Mail on Sunday column. I am not going to berate Hitchens ... well, not much. Compared to his bloat brother, Chris, Peter isn't so bad. He has been magnificent on the Iraq war and the people who made it; he simply lacks a sense of proportion and has this need to turn a tut into a scream.

His text is mostly interesting as a major, if unstated, aspect of the Eurosceptic mentality. Talk to these folk conversationally, or in debate, and they will say things about bureaucracy (as if we didn't have a perfectly splendid one of our own) and about decisions taken over our heads (as if our dear government didn't devote its talents to doing little else). It also works up a lather over aspirational small print in the Treaty of Rome concerning federal powers never likely to be achieved, and hardly the coming of the Great Beast if they were. The real motives are different.

Putting side the altogether rational Rupert Murdoch, who has been guarding his vast percentage of print and visual media from the possibility that, one day, there might be a European law sticking him at under a fifth, the chief motive of the Euro-haters is a delicious, luxuriated-in and entirely irrational fear of Germany.

We have always had large pockets this delusional thing. As a precocious schoolboy, I read a piece in the Sunday Express marking the formal ending of British occupational troops in, I think, 1955, with an assurance that Germany's statehood was not real. It was tolerated to function under the eagle eye of the British Army of the Rhine. This force, whatever might be said about change, was still the British army of occupation. Hugh Dalton, Attlee's first Chancellor, reacted to the Schuman Coal and Steel Community, precursor of the EEC/EU, by invoking Germany and asking God to forbid "that that black ship should ever put to sea again".

Ten years after the second world war, these might have been understandable anxieties however mistaken. AJP Taylor, 20 years on, during the 1975 referendum, arguing that Germany was making her bid for power behind the mask of "Europe", was, at that time, a crazy flight full into the teeth of 10-feet high reality. Said in 2007, such trembling horrors put us in barmpot country.

Observe Hitchens' perversion of evidence. No doubt M Sarkozy did get the nuclear codes; he also went jogging, exchanged insincere felicitations with Jacques Chirac and walked through a ceremonial guard of soldiers. Why pick on the nuclear codes as point of reference? Is it suggested that the new president was going to hand them on to Frau-Kanzler Merkel, or that it would matter if he did, Germany having no nuclear weapons? We are into smears and the hysteria that incites smears. All that done, the water flooded with mud, we come to the final perfect rubbish. This lady, moderate conservative, the daughter of Protestant pastor, is "the supreme ruler of France".

Oh dear, as I said: barmpot, but universally refutable barmpot. Angela Merkel, by a small majority in an impeccably democratic election, held according to rules very much fairer and more representative of the voters than our frowsty lottery, is the head of government in the Federal Republic. She is also, over six months, president of that Sanhedrin of Satan, the European Commission. She was held up by medieval reactionaries in eastern Europe in her efforts at conciliation with Russia, but is winning wide respect despite this. She is the "supreme ruler of France" the way the Guardian's Mr Rusbridger secretly directs the Daily Telegraph.

France and Germany made their peace and a fruitful alliance in Rheims in July 1962. How can any sane person think that lasting reconciliation between the heirs of 1870, 1914 and 1939, anything but a supreme act of statesmanship? I think it probably the best, most constructive and wisest thing done by any government in the last 100 years. If the British had shown sense toward that earlier Schuman plan, instead of brushing it off because "the Durham miners will never wear it," we could have been part of the reconciliation and genuinely "at the heart of Europe". If so, we would have been among friends, something which so many British people, flying nearer the ground than Hitchens, still cannot bring themselves to believe or rejoice at.

The Germany and France so little disposed to war, so liberated from imperialist delusions (France, in that same year, 1962, finally out of the Algerian horror-show), have a thing or two to teach Britain. How can Hitchens who sees the war and death out of sight of an American enterprise condemned by France and Germany before it started, and joined in this by the great majority of European states, treat the German-French embrace as somehow malign and threatening? Germany is not responsible for the long catalogue of "security" restrictions, surveillance and dereliction of constitutional law under John "Crackdown" Reid. We reap there the consequences of too long, too servile, adherence to the United States, the gilded spar of a "special relationship" and the actual subordination so perfectly compressed by Mr Bush as "Yo, Blair ".

I would not myself call that melancholy excuse for a president "supreme ruler of Britain", but it has looked like it recently. How very much better it would be if, instead, we could recognise modern Germany, impeccably liberal-democratic, a vastly fairer society than ours, enjoying wholly superior public services and a country chronically averse to war, meddling and international aggrandisement, as the best friend we could have and, frankly, something of a model.

rank_220.title: Bush's euroscepticism
rank_220.text:
It is striking how the media coverage of the G8 deal on climate change has differed in Britain and the US as the text of last week's joint statement has been chewed over on both sides of the Atlantic.

Much of the British press echoed the Downing Street line that the statement was a breakthrough. The reaction in the US, after reporters were briefed by the White House, was far more sceptical, emphasising what was not agreed in Heiligendamm. In particular, the American coverage underlined President Bush's refusal to endorse a specific goal for reducing global emissions.

A commentary in the conservative Wall Street Journal went as far as to hail the final communique as a victory for the US approach to climate change - voluntary targets and economic incentives for technological innovation - over the European prescription of mandatory caps and carbon trading. The column was triumphantly titled: "Bush 1, Greens 0".

The actual text of the statement is deliberately hard to interpret, but it makes it clear that those two very different approaches to global warming remain unreconciled. The pledge to "consider seriously" the goal of halving global emissions by 2050 sounds vaguely encouraging but does not commit anyone to anything.

Downing Street made much of the statement's reference to the leading role of the UNFCCC (the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change) suggesting US acquiescence to that framework. But when the UNFCCC was mentioned in the joint statement following the Gleneagles agreement in 2005, it also included a group "commitment" to UNFCCC. In the eyes of the Bush administration's lawyers, it reflected little more than a requirement to pass on emissions figures to the UN.

Bush, meanwhile, won endorsement for his proposal to host its own meeting of 15 of the biggest polluters ahead of the next UN climate conference in Bali at the end of this year. That meeting is likely to see another US attempt to rally support for an American-led approach to climate change, which emphasises voluntary targets and technological evolution.

In effect, it clears the way for twin-track negotiations - one based on a US agenda, the other on a European agenda.

What is new in the Heiligendamm statement is an end date for the negotiations of 2009. It does nothing to make that deadline any more realistic, but it does leave up to a year for Bush's successor to put his or her own stamp on any final deal.

rank_278.title: Eurosceptics are swimming against the tide
rank_278.text:
Last night, 250 self-styled young trendies gathered at an exclusive central London nightclub to mark the launch of the "I want a referendum" campaign. Their mission is to persuade the British government to hold a referendum on the EU reform treaty. Some of the attendees would be more accustomed to sipping champagne at a "high society" bash.

The organisers of the event would want you to believe Euroscepticism is the trendy issue of the moment - that their suspicion of Europe is hitting the zeitgeist, and that the young of Britain are in a state of anger and outrage about the UK's relationship with the EU.

The gathering at the swanky London nightclub may reinforce the position of those who want the UK to have a distant relationship with the EU. But it swims against the tide of the close business, cultural and educational linkages between the UK and the rest of Europe.

The combined result of the EU's free movement and low-cost airlines has been an explosion in the number of visits made by British people to the continent. Last year, British nationals made 53 million visits to the rest of Europe. Whether these are by groups of young men going to Prague for a stag weekend, football fans travelling to Barcelona or couples seeking romance in Paris, visits to the continent have become an established component of contemporary British life.

Since EU rules guarantee the right of people to live in another member state, thousands of British people seeking a warmer climate and a new life have moved to live on the continent. The renowned British contingent in Spain, which dominates many towns on the Costa del Sol, now numbers 750,000, while there are 300,000 British people living in France. Many people own holiday homes in these countries, too.

People from the UK are seeking business and professional opportunities on the continent, with 750,000 British companies now doing business with the rest of Europe. The European single market is now the largest market in the world. It provides a fountain of opportunity for British entrepreneurs, with a reach now to almost 500 million consumers, many more than the US market has.

As students, many young Britons spend a term or even a year improving their language skills and experiencing a new culture. (More than 7,000 students from this country take part every year in Erasmus, the European Commission's educational programme for higher education). Furthermore, the importance of sporting and cultural linkages such as Eurovision, European football and French/ Italian food should not be underestimated.

So the links are growing stronger at a time when some wish for us to retreat from the EU. But what do all these closer tiers with Europe have to do with the reform treaty and a referendum? Well, while some of those calling for a referendum wish to have a genuine debate about Europe, others wish to scupper, undermine and at times dismantle the UK's relationship with the EU.

As the former chancellor Ken Clarke said, many of the sceptics would call for a referendum if even a comma were added to the constitutional treaty. These visceral sceptics see a referendum on the EU treaty as a way of saying a firm no not only to the proposals in a treaty but also to the EU as a whole. They want the benefits of involvement with the EU but are reluctant to enshrine these.

Many of the sceptics demand a referendum because they say the treaty entails a significant transfer of power from the UK to the EU. They point to an increase in majority voting in a number of areas. But the loss of the British veto also means the loss of the veto for 26 other member states. It means the UK is more likely to be able to force through beneficial legislation on issues such as energy liberalisation and the distribution of EU aid.

One of the most powerful advocates of the realpolitik of majority voting was Mrs Thatcher, who transferred several policy areas to majority voting in the Single European Act of 1986. She later wrote in her memoirs: "British businesses would be among those most likely to benefit from an opening-up of other countries' markets [.] The price which we would have to pay to achieve a Single Market with all its economic benefits, though, was more majority voting in the Community."

Perhaps some of the 250 youngsters attending the party, many of whom were born during Mrs Thatcher's prime ministership, would do well to read the relevant passages in her memoirs more closely.

rank_230.title: Not EU again
rank_230.text:
It's EU summit time again: the quarterly event that in some states inspires the occasional worthwhile debate about the future or meaning of the union, or the validity of a specific proposal from an interesting perspective, or maybe a media piece about an EU commissioner or institution. In the UK, on the other hand - or is it just England? - it is an event that unleashes yet another round of Euroscepticism, as EU-bashing is euphemistically known. Or rather it merely gives licence to an avid increase in the residual Euroscepticism - which is boring and repetitive, at best, and often downright misinformed. Worse still, it is slowly making the UK and its predictable lines less and less influential in the union.

The EU is a great success - whether as a security policy among its member states, in that it has prevented wars for 60 years, and still does; whether as a novel historical creation, an experiment in pooled sovereignty for the greater good; or whether as a massive trading bloc that has increased the overall wealth and quality of life of its citizens. It undoubtedly has many faults, in everything from policies to institutions, but the historical perspective suggests these are less than its overall achievements - yet these are rarely, if ever, mentioned in England. Instead, a predictable charge sheet against the EU is produced and decried ever more shrilly.

The main points on that sheet may be summarised thus: • we joined the common market, not a political union, and it's still the market we want and no more; • however, there is now a continental plot to create a European superstate; • the Eurocrats who make up the massive bureaucracy in Brussels have too much say over our lives since they decide everything; • we just give tons of money to the EU and get little in return.

Nonsense is the polite way of responding to this litany. Nonsense, because it is misinformed; and nonsense because the cumulative effect of this list is that it bars England from contributing to the European debate, for its own benefit and the benefit of others, at a meaningful level.

The misinformation stems from a basic truth, systematically hidden by governments over the years: all policy decisions, on every issue, from budgets to areas of red tape to the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), are decided by the member states, not the hated and amorphous Brussels and its bureaucracy - which for the budget and tasks it handles, all decided by the member states, is actually quite small. It is the British government that has not only committed the state to every step in the EU, but has often actually led integrative policy - and that includes Conservative governments and especially Saint Margaret. While best known in the Isles for demanding her rebate money back from the EU, she was also the one who signed up to a whole string of integrative measures, including the Common European Act; and gave her blessing to a variety of initiatives that were forerunners of the vilified treaty being discussed at today's summit. She just never bothered telling her electorate about it.

The reality, as Baroness Thatcher and all her successors realised, is that time and events move on, regardless of sentiment. The UK may have joined the common market, but that was in the early 1970s. The world and the EU have evolved out of necessity, and constantly demanding it stays still as the UK wants it is simply unrealistic and narrow - if not downright simplistic. Because what the charge sheet actually boils down to is not a reasoned argument, but this: all in all, we are England and we don't want that national quality to be diluted in any way, or have a group of foreigners we helped save 60 years ago, tell us what to do. Ever.

This is the EU as a zero-sum game: everything one member state loses is a gain to another or others, and vice versa. In this reading, the "pooling of sovereignty" towards "an ever-closer union" which is what the UK actually signed up to upon joining the union, since both terms are in the founding treaty, is constantly and narrowly interpreted as a continental grab of English independence. That is the Sun and the Daily Telegraph reading of English identity, which for some reason the rest of the nation seems comfortable with. It is about Huns and ungrateful perfidious French and silly Italians and smelly Spaniards grabbing the English rose. It is so intellectually bereft, not to mention downright offensive, that it should not be worth talking about - yet it is the residual image, and many in the union are beginning to tire of it. If nothing else, it's repetitive and boring.

Instead of this drivel, it is about time the English engaged themselves, and the EU, in proper debate about the future of the union and the place of England in it: a debate about the realistic capabilities of the one with and without the other, a debate that poses real alternatives instead of post-dated demands. The current debate is set to the level of the Sun and Daily Mail journalists - a species, by the way, never known to actually set foot in Brussels - and is no better than a slanging match about the past and a zero-sum game in the present. Worse still, it is so childishly offensive, that England is losing it.

rank_264.title: Thomas Kielinger: The bulldog voice of Britain
rank_264.text:
More pit bull than lapdog: that's how I would describe the combative DNA of the British media. There's often a touch of class to the jousting, for sure, but equally often the fighting descends into a slugfest with no holds barred. That's how the world has come to see, and mostly enjoy, the British print media in particular: hooked on personal drama, raw and adversarial, given to the robust exchange customary in an open society and an old democracy, at that.

Nowhere is this more true than in the great fight over the new Lisbon treaty. Europe seems to trigger some of the most visceral reactions in the British psyche. If you are a eurosceptic - which is how about 70 per cent of the British people would describe themselves - you only need turn to history to find all the relevant buzzwords to get worked up about Europe and the bureaucrats in Brussels.

'The Last Supper' screamed the Sun on Friday in its inner pages, in its typically punning fashion - which, happily, is never very far from even the most bitter argument. 'Brown surrenders Britain's power to Europe over dinner', read the subhead. It must have sent shudders down the spine of true blue patriots to think that Churchill's 'We shall never surrender' should have been betrayed among the fudge majeure of some Brussels horse trading.

How is it that the eurosceptic media have such a field day within British society? I don't want to get into the unique geographic circumscription of an island nation that has always kept the continent at arm's length while at the same time embedding itself deeply all over the globe.

My take is both more practical and topical: I suspect the powers that be over the past 20 years have been covertly eurosceptic, belying all assertions to the contrary, like wanting to be 'at the heart of Europe'.

Gordon Brown is a case in point. Ten years ago he laid down the law on the five tests that would have to be met before the pound could ever be considered ready to join the euro - in essence saying 'never'. Since then he has acted as the wary partner of Europe, behaving like a schoolmistress telling unruly children to learn their economic algebra or forever be hoist on the Lisbon-agenda petard of the spring of 2000.

Brown talked of 'red lines' in the way Margaret Thatcher kept banging on about 'wanting my money back' in her time. And back she did get the British rebate, just like her successor-but-three got his red lines written into the new treaty. Unlike Thatcher, however, scant benefit may be derived from it to restore Brown's tarnished reputation.

With successive governments professing to protect 'British interests' against an ever-encroaching EU, how can one expect the British public, and the media in its wake, to be anything other than overwhelmingly eurosceptic? A rational argument about 'Why Europe?' has never been considered necessary, nor has the EU done enough to enhance its credibility as an enterprise living up to its stated reforms. Into this vacuum the media has rushed with a vengeance - which is what you get when politicians cede the battleground.

Like a reluctant follower of fashion, I, too, began to think of the debate in terms of the 'xenophobic Murdoch press' et al versus some more enlightened minority views elsewhere in the British media. Lately, I have been completely disabused of this rather shallow approach. For one thing, concern about an increasingly regulatory Brussels bureaucracy has little to do with xenophobia but is rooted, instead, in a deep aversion towards overweening, nannying systems trying to lord it over all of us. This sentiment is widely shared across the continent. For another, I was fascinated by the website response to an article by Michael White in the Guardian of 18 October, in which he broadly outlined a positive approach to the EU, pouring mildly phrased scorn on the 'no surrender' diehards.

Surely, many people would have nodded approval of this line? Well, surprise, surprise: the response, over 16 pages, was mainly critical. Obviously, euroscepticism runs high even among Guardianistas, dooming all attempts to neatly separate advocates from adversaries, europhiles from eurosceptics.

True, there were some jarring notes - like the 'peace in our time' jibe Michael Connarty, chairman of the Commons European scrutiny committee, threw at Foreign Secretary David Miliband during the latter's grilling by the committee this week. Brown the new Neville Chamberlain, selling out to the Brussels dictatorship? Give me a break. But then, hasn't 'European scrutiny' always entailed digging up false analogies? Every country is heir to its past, for better or worse.

Ideally, Europe should modernise to the degree where neither red lines nor red herrings are warranted any longer. Fat chance.

· Thomas Kielinger reports from the UK for the German national daily Die Welt

rank_257.title: Will Hutton: Tongue-tied Britain is losing its voice
rank_257.text:
In her short speech feting the architectural marvel that is the new St Pancras last week, the Queen commented that this is not just the remarkable rebirth of a great station, but it makes the whole country closer to Europe.

That, in the monarch's mind, is self-evidently a good thing. But it chimes awkwardly with an increasingly anti-foreigner, jingoistic, 'British jobs for British workers', Eurosceptic culture. Euroscepticism has morphed. It's questionable whether any coalition could be built to support the construction of the Channel Tunnel and high-speed rail link to Europe today. The Queen speaks for a passing generation and culture.

It is a tragedy and as a country we are diminished. Our geography, interests and so much of our humanity are intertwined with a continent of which we are part. The self-generated hostility to Europe and attendant cynicism leaches into the fabric of what we do, who we are and the choices we make. We will not like the consequences.At the same time as the Queen was getting ready to go to St Pancras, it was disclosed that fewer than half British schoolchildren now study a single European language for GCSE. Blame was laid with a 2004 government decision to stop making language study mandatory after 14. But the fall-away in European language studies long predates 2004; indeed, it was one of the reasons the government took the decision.

Lord Dearing, appointed last year by the government to investigate the drop, says one explanation is that learning languages is intellectually tough. But it has always been. What has changed is our culture. We no longer value speaking a European language, in part because we don't have to, but also, I believe, because we disdain Europe and Europeans. For what we are witnessing is not a gradual move; children are voting with their feet in incredible numbers because they feel nobody values speaking an European language.

Only 28.7 per cent of students now take French GCSE and a mere 11.5 per cent take German. It may be true that English has emerged as an international language, so that making the effort to study a European language has a lower practical pay-off, but that is disputable, as I will argue later. Again, the international use of English has not suddenly emerged over the last few years. There is another agency of change: virulent, toxic, culturally embedded Euroscepticism.

It is alive in the current debate over migration. It saturates the media. Newspapers such as the Sunday Express can wrongly claim that Britain is to be policed by a Euro-police or the News of the World that the Royal coat of arms will be taken off British passports, with no comeback (examples cited in the current edition of E!Sharp magazine).

Even the BBC is affected; a recent report that made the tacit assumption that a silly spat over which city a treaty should be signed in was the best that could be expected from Europeans set my teeth on edge. It saturates our view of Europe's economic performance even when, as with today's Germany, it is doing very well. It has begun to be very unpleasant indeed.

My eldest daughter, who switched from studying German at university, partly changed because she wearied of having constantly to justify what she was doing. But the impact goes much wider than choices over language GCSEs. In the latest European Commission recruitment round, according to the Economist, just 2 per cent of applicants were British. The number of British graduates applying to be interns in the Commission, as preparation for a job, is running at 40 per cent of the level five years ago. The attraction of City salaries is part of the explanation, but, again, they have always been high. What is changing is our newly virulent Eurosceptic culture. Go to a party and tell your friends you want to work in Brussels and you will be derided and mocked.

This is horizon-shrinking, mean, joyless and self-defeating. If part of the excuse for our uninterest in speaking foreign languages is that English is now the world language, it should not follow that the languages others speak are of no use or cultural importance. Indeed, there is evidence that the internationalisation of English is changing structure and use so much that native English speakers are at a double disadvantage. Not only can they not make themselves understood in the language of others, they cannot navigate the complexities of the new Globish, an English mutating into something very different from the English we speak.

It also leads to a genuine battiness about our place in the world. Even as the Americans have learnt they need friends, we British have acquired unilateral instincts with a fraction of their economic and military power. Of Gordon Brown's recent catalogue of misjudgments, perhaps the most extraordinary was his commitment to create 'British jobs for British workers' - a BNP slogan. Our cultural sensibility is inured to the underlying ethnic apartheid that his words implied. Nobody in his inner circle thought to warn him and too few picked up on it at the time.

But I think the worst aspect of this disdain for Europe is its cramping inwardness. I am a governor of Hockerill School in Bishop's Stortford, a state comprehensive that the Times this year ranked as the number one school in the country - public or private. Fifteen years ago, it was an also-ran. But it is no accident that the school's new academic excellence and intellectual vitality are via its unparalleled commitment to language teaching (students generally take two language GCSEs) and its commitment to fill some of its boarding places with students from the EU.

The interaction of cultural diversity and the intellectual rigour involved in studying language - history is taught in French - has meant that ordinary kids from ordinary homes comfortably outperform pupils at expensive private schools such as Westminster and Winchester.

It is a precious achievement, but in today's climate, too few state schools will dare to follow or get cultural or community support if they try. The fast route to academic success is not raising the school leaving age as proposed last week; rather, it would be making two language GCSEs mandatory. The wider spill-over - on our imagination, on business, on culture - would be so beneficial. As it is, we are fast becoming a nation of dumbed-down nationalists snarling across the Channel. It's not, I think, what most of us want.

rank_201.title: Small change
rank_201.text:
Denmark has, like Britain, enjoyed a decade-long economic boom. We share membership of the European Union and, like the British, still have our own currency, the krone. At a referendum in 2000 the Danes said no to the euro. Some argue that positioning ourselves outside the eurozone has benefited our respective economies. This may to some extent be true of Britain, but the krone was always aligned with the German deutschmark and today we are pegged to the euro. So the potential benefits of maintaining the krone is mostly symbolic - and, to my mind, rather questionable.

Being a small nation, the Danes are with some justification wary of being swallowed by the big bad union. Although we have been in the EU since 1972, both Danish political wings have had Eurosceptic factions. Back in 1992, I - along with many other liberals - voted no to the Maastricht treaty. Many of us later on regretted our vote, because it put us in the same chauvinistic boat as European rightwingers such as Jean-Marie Le Pen and Jorg Heider. It is important to understand that Euroscepticism in Denmark is not just a rightwing phenomenon. However, over the last 10 years the rightwing Danish People's party, which once again formed the parliamentary foundation for a centre-right government, increasingly came to define patriotism and what being Danish means. Their smug version of Danishness is not a sentiment that all Danes subscribe to. However, in today's political landscape the Danish People's party remains a dominant player. Fear of everything unknown is widespread in Denmark today - hence our permanent and unjustified paranoia of being overrun by Muslim immigrants. Apart from the xenophobia, the most depressing part of the recent election was that the debate was dominated by money, taxes and the issue of personal rights. The Iraq war, where Danish troops are still fighting alongside the Americans and British, was hardly discussed during the electioneering. Nor were other international topics.

It seems as though we as a nation are cuddling up and hiding from a world that we perceive as a threat to our wealth and privileges. To me, holding on to the Danish krone has come to signify that we are avoiding full European cooperation. Danes are willing to benefit from being in the union, but want to constantly keep a foot in the door. National currencies are highly symbolic, but today the anti-euro lobby is the home of reactionary tendencies. The EU may be problematic, but not being in it would be foolish - which is why I believe Denmark should join the euro as soon as possible. This view is, however, not shared by the majority of my fellow countrymen.

rank_176.title: Semi-detached Digby
rank_176.text:
"Anyone can rat but it takes a certain amount of ingenuity to re-rat." So said Winston Churchill.

That will sum up what many Labour party members feel as Digby Jones's (private) revelation that he intends to leave the government before the next election is splashed across the newspapers this morning.

It is a good principle of low politics to treat defectors well, "pour encourager les autres". Quentin Davies has made effective attacks on Conservative Euroscepticism. Shaun Woodward presides over Northern Ireland from the cabinet.

The difference with Jones is that he was always clear he was not joining the Labour party, still less the Labour tribe. He took up the offer from Gordon Brown to go out and bat for Britain and British business worldwide - a West Midlands version of Prince Andrew, perhaps - as long as he did not need to sully himself with the world of party politics. This insistence on being a semi-detached and apolitical member of the government partly explained the discontent among trade unionists and Labour peers over his appointment, along with his vociferous opposition to the minimum wage before 1997.

In office, Jones has never been prepared to defend the full range of government policy, and broke with collective responsibility entirely over the taxation of non-doms. It would have made more sense to make him a trade envoy or part of an expert group than to appoint this kind of crossbench minister.

So news of Jones's future departure is not much of a surprise, though the timing of it will not please Downing Street at all. Jones may be irked that at least two of just 12 participants in a private discussion seem to have spilled the beans. A great many Westminster and Whitehall discussions take place on a private basis or under the Chatham House rule. Perhaps 99% of the time it is observed. But the only way to be sure that something won't get out is not to stay it. Never Jones's strong point.

However, Jones's larger-than-life persona can also lead people to underestimate how his views have changed in recent years. He had moved a fair way from advocating the "slash the state" Thatcherite politics than many in the labour movement associate him with.

He has become evangelical about one of Gordon Brown's core political ideas - the need to improve skills and to unlock potential if Britain is to compete in the global economy. And his commitment to trade promotion abroad highlights the importance of government acting to attract inward investment: an issue which has tripped Boris Johnson up in the London mayoral election after his ill-judged plans to close down London's inward investment offices in Beijing, Shanghai, Delhi, Mumbai and Brussels came under fire from the City.

For some in small business, this shift in Jones's outlook will simply prove that the CBI and the big corporations never look out for the little guy. But it is indicative of a more interesting - and underrated - political shift. Despite 30 years of anti-government rhetoric, on issues from climate change to global financial instability, the call is always for government to act. The Tory modernisers believe they have become electable because they are running on Labour spending plans and eschewing tax cuts. Perhaps this will lead them to mirror Bill Clinton's move to the centre in acknowledging the end of big government: in their case they could announce that, in the age of climate change, "the era of small government" is over. (And what a shame Gordon Brown probably won't do so first).

But the Jones episode also demonstrates the pitfalls of "big tent" politics. Reaching across party boundaries can be good politics; and can offer a wider range of inputs to policy too.

But Gordon Brown's difficulty has been in giving his government a clear sense of political direction. A big tent cannot do that because definition cannot be achieved without saying things with which some people will disagree. Politics is also about picking the right fights. We don't know yet which one Gordon Brown will choose.

To stick to the tactics of triangulation is to fail to adapt to the fact that the Conservatives are now learning from three successive defeats. As the opposition ape progressive language and aspirations, this is to offer to fight a general election on David Cameron's terms. If voters believe there is little difference between the parties, the election is simply a referendum on the incumbents, not a choice between alternative governments.

And that would be an election - with or without Jones on the campaign trail - that Gordon Brown would struggle to win.

rank_252.title: Giles Merritt: End EU navel-gazing
rank_252.text:
The EU has no coherent strategy on many issues. It has only sketchy economic policies toward Russia; ambitions, but no game plan, to become a player in the Middle East; and, despite its original leadership on the Kyoto Protocol, no successor program on climate change. And the biggest question of all – how to engage with China, India, and other giants of the future – has received virtually no attention from EU-level policymakers.

These issues require attention now, and an integral part of the EU's search for new global strategies should be to invite, rather than avoid, criticism of its activities. If the EU is to lift its gaze from its navel to the horizon, it must reconcile the very different views that exist across Europe of its place in the world and its own best interests. That means engaging with those shades of political opinion that the European commission and the European parliament consider "eurosceptic."

The counter-pressure, of course, is that EU officialdom feels unloved and unappreciated. There is an almost embattled culture among many senior officials, who fear that fanning the flames of dissent among Europe's voters could one day knock European unity off course.

Euroscepticism represents everything the Eurocrats dislike. They worry that politicians and journalists who oppose their strategies for closer political and economic union could yet tip the balance of public opinion against the EU. Eurosceptic politicians elected to the European parliament are often treated with the disdain that true believers reserve for the infidel.

Yet it is ludicrous to think that eurosceptics represent a silent majority that could rise up and destroy the EU. Popular support for the European project has barely faltered over the last 25 years, and has even begun to strengthen of late.

At the beginning of the 1980s, when Europe was faltering and the media catchword was "eurosclerosis," 50% of people polled for the Eurobarometer surveys viewed membership as positive for their country. About 19% said its effects were negative, and the rest didn't know. Today, overall support for the EU stands at 57%, and the share of people unhappy with it has dropped to 15%.

There are now no EU countries where eurosceptics are in the majority, and the widespread impression that citizens in Western and Eastern Europe alike are turning their backs on the EU is wrong. The reality is that even though voters may find the EU remote, most appreciate the need for Europe to unite in a world where China, India, and other fast-developing countries are set to challenge it.

Reassured by this groundswell of support, the Eurocrats should be fostering a much more pluralistic approach to EU policymaking and debate. The commission should be organizing public debates that give equal prominence to dissenting views. Eurocrats must learn that euroscepticism is fundamentally healthy, because it invites closer examination of the policy options open to Europe, and thus increases the involvement of ordinary people in the EU's policymaking process. And greater involvement quickly leads to better understanding of the issues at stake, and the reasons why some policies have been adopted that challenge or even override the sovereign powers of individual countries.

For half a century, Europe's integrationists have sought unquestioning acceptance of their efforts. That demand must be abandoned. It will probably take several generations before a workable EU-wide political system emerges, but the first step is for the EU to encourage people to have their say, however uncomfortable that may be.

rank_185.title: Charles Kennedy warns Lib Dems against pandering to Euroscepticism
rank_185.text:
The former leader of the Liberal Democrats, Charles Kennedy, has warned his successor of "pandering" to Euroscepticism after signs that the EU might be slipping down the party's agenda.

Speaking in a debate on Europe on the penultimate day of the party's Bournemouth conference, Kennedy – now president of the European Movement – said Europe was a "litmus test issue" for the party, and raised doubts about the wisdom of the Lib Dems' strategy when the House of Commons voted on the Lisbon treaty in March.

Then three frontbenchers resigned after defying party orders to abstain in the vote on calls for a referendum on the treaty. Alistair Carmichael, Tim Farron and David Heath resigned their posts so they could vote in favour.

Yesterday Kennedy said: "We will not - and I think to an extent perhaps we learnt this lesson in the division lobbies of the House of Commons earlier this year - benefit, far less profit politically, by pandering to any extent to Euroscepticism."

"This party is at its best when we have taken principled stands on foreign affairs. Ashdown on the plight of the Hong Kong Chinese and during my own time on Iraq. With Nick Clegg as leader - a former member of the European parliament and one who is personally and politically so instinctively the embodiment of modern Europeanism, we are well-placed in the coming months .... to give a clarion call, which is clear and consistent of proper, engaged Liberal Democrat Europeanism."

He added: "The truth is those of a profound Eurosceptical disposition - even if we are seen to trim and row somewhat in their direction - will, come polling day, find 100 other reasons for not voting Liberal Democrat while saying thank you for any succour or comfort we might give them..."

The party leadership also sought to shut down reports that they had jettisoned a long-held policy pledge to join the euro. Nick Clegg gave an interview at the weekend suggesting the euro was no longer "an urgent priority".

Summing up at the end of the debate, Edward Davey MP spoke in favour of the UK joining the single currency, but conceded that winning a referendum on the euro would not be possible at present.

He said: "We recognise that we couldn't join the euro overnight, that we would need to win a referendum first, and that in a practical world that is some time off.

"But as time goes on - as the pound goes through the floor, as the cost of staying out grows - we will not be the only ones arguing the case for the single currency."

The main point of yesterday's debate was to ask the party to back reform of the EU's farming and fisheries policies as well as more accountable budgets. Their policy paper - Shaping our World through a Stronger Europe - calls for the UK to be at the centre of the EU, driving closer cooperation on climate change, justice, security and defence.

Opening the debate, Sir Colin Budd said Gordon Brown's heart was "clearly not in it" on Europe and that under a Tory government there was a "clear and strong risk" that the UK would be moved to the fringes of the EU.

Jonathan Fryer, chairman of the Liberal International British group, said the party was being too soft on Labour and the Tories by describing their approach to Europe as "half-hearted". He said: "Sometimes I think this party is too polite. A 'half-hearted approach to Europe'? Well, pardon the Anglo-Saxonism, but bollocks."

rank_112.title: Hugh Muir's diary: 17 March 2009
rank_112.text:
As the Eurosceptic Tories get a wigging from the president of the European commission, along comes yet another group of freedom fighters, shaking yet more fists towards Brussels. This time it's former Tory CEO Sir Paul Judge's turn to launch "The Jury Team": and begin the search for election candidates keen to be part of all that they despise. The idea is start small, think big; and with that in mind we should not be surprised that few of Sir Paul's old colleagues at Westminster seemed to know anything about yesterday's launch. Why, he didn't even tell his MP, Peter Luff, that he was setting up a new party. That's just rude: Judge is president of Luff's local Conservative Association in Worcester. So why is Sir Paul doing it? Conservatives are baffled, for, as we see, there is a healthy strain of Euroscepticism within their own party. There always seemed to be enough bile to go around.

• Read the headlines. "Home Office gave illegal instructions to immigration officials" is one. "MI5 criticised for role in case of torture, rendition and secrecy" - there's another. Many lawyers in government, perhaps too many, but still, they need help with this legal stuff. Luckily help is coming. Staff, we learn, will benefit from a "Home Office Masterclass: Joshua Rozenberg on law" on the basis that the former BBC correspondent turned all-round legal pundit "has had a ringside seat at the majority of the department's most significant cases". "What is the perception of the Home Office through legal eyes?" will be a key topic. Hope he doesn't make them cry.

• With Gordon setting out his stall on nuclear power today, what more do we know of Justine Thornton, the lawyer for power company E.ON who shares a home and a life with climate change secretary Ed Miliband? Could this Justine Thornton be the same person who manoeuvred herself to become co-ordinator of the energy group for Sera, Labour's environmental campaign? The one who at the Sera AGM in 2007 argued in favour of David Miliband becoming president, despite the fact he was rampantly pro-nuclear power, a policy diametrically opposite to Sera's policy against nuclear energy for the preceding 25 years? If she declared an interest at the time, no one remembers it; perhaps she didn't have to. But the tussle and its outcome certainly led to members tendering their resignations. No doubt it still raises a smile at home.

• No surprise that a few weeks into the job, Sir Paul Stephenson, Britain's top cop, should seek to reshuffle the pack. Each new man has new ideas, different priorities. He's smart too. For by moving deputy assistant commissioner Stephen Roberts from a senior berth in HR to a backroom role, developing the apparently crucial relationship between Oxford University and the Met, the commissioner has enhanced the force's links with academia. Sir Ian Blair went to Oxford, remember. These things matter. Sir Paul has also enhanced his own ability to deal with criticism widely expected to form part of the race and faith inquiry commissioned by Boris Johnson. Roberts had become a lightning rod for complaints from black officers that they were failing to gain promotion. Now, when the day arrives, Sir Paul can say he was ahead of the curve. Crisis averted. Roll on the next one. That's the Yard. That's how it works.

• And finally, we have travelled through days of horror and hope in Northern Ireland - with the return of murderous terrorism, but also a united response from the various politicians. Many things will result from this. Here is one of them. Last week George Weiss, aka the surrealist Rainbow George, contacted the Electoral Commission and formerly de-registered Make Politicians History, the four-year-old protest party under which banner he fought the 2007 assembly elections in Belfast. "Having seen the way the politicians there have come together since the attacks, I have come to rather admire them," says Rainbow, strangely subdued. Make Politicians History is now history. Amid the japes, real life.

• This article was amended on Wednesday 18 March 2009. It was the president of the European commission, José Manuel Barroso, not the president of the European parliament who said he regretted the withdrawal of the Conservative party from the main centre-right grouping in the European parliament. This has been amended.

rank_288.title: Richard Corbett: A sop to Conservative headbangers
rank_288.text:
The decision by Christopher Beazley to in effect resign the Conservative whip in the European parliament should not come as a big surprise. Chris has long despaired of the Tory leadership's tactic of appeasing the rabid Euroscepticism of the party's rightwing, and long ago decided to retire from parliament in June because he had had enough.

As I have said before, Europhiles are an endangered species in the Tory party. Beazley has, predictably, been crucified by the likes of Conservative Home, the same forum where a party member was described as a "traitor" because he dared to point out a few benefits of the European Union. However, Christopher's insistence that he could not "watch and say nothing while the Tories walk away from their allies, friends and colleagues in Europe" – and his plaintive expression that "I cannot watch my country head for the rocks, which it will do if Cameron becomes prime minister and has no allies in the major governments of the European Union" – should strike a chord with many of the remaining Tory moderates.

Over the last 20 years or so, Labour and the Conservatives have punched above their weight in the two largest political groups in the European Parliament and, since 1999, so have the Liberal Democrats. Now Britain will have no presence in one of them (except for those - and I know of at least one besides Beazley - who will not follow Cameron's silly instruction).

So, why do it?

The official reason for the Conservatives' decision to leave the European People's party-European Democrats grouping is that the EPP has some federalists in it. This is bizarre: the EPP has federalist members, but it also has many non-federalists (apart from the Conservatives, there are Ulster Unionists, Swedish Conservatives, French Gaullists, Czech Civic Democrats and various others). But anyway, so what? The European parliament doesn't decide on the level of EU integration. It is national governments and parliaments that decide on that – the European parliament only decides on the content of EU legislation in areas that the EU is already responsible for. On most of this, the Conservatives and other EPP parties normally agree.

The reality is that this position is nothing to do with whether the EPP is federalist or not – it is David Cameron giving a sop to the headbangers on the right of his party whose votes he needed when he was elected as leader. The issue doesn't really figure very much in public debate – Europe as an issue is well down the list of priorities for people – but it does matter to the "blue rinse" brigade. In other words, symbolism has prevailed over reality.

But in trying to keep the party faithful happy, Cameron still risks embarrassment in this enterprise. Even if the Tories do succeed in taking the governing Czech Civic Democrats (who are as riven as the Tories by domestic splits and have just lost a vote of no confidence) and the Polish Law and Justice party with them, they will still be searching for MEPs from at least four other countries to form a group.
